docs.text:
name: Macromolecule
description: A large molecule, such as a polymer, lipid, or macrocycle
title: macromolecule
comments:
- check on classification of lipids
from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
exact_mappings:
- Wikipedia:Macromolecule
is_a: Molecule
slot_usage:
  has_submolecules:
    name: has_submolecules
    range: Molecule
attributes:
  has_atom_occurrences:
    name: has_atom_occurrences
    description: An individuated atom in the context of a chemical structure.
    title: has atom occurrences
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    alias: has_atom_occurrences
    owner: Macromolecule
    domain_of:
    - Molecule
    range: AtomOccurrence
    multivalued: true
    inlined: true
    inlined_as_list: true
    minimum_cardinality: 2
  has_bonds:
    name: has_bonds
    description: The set of all bonds connecting atoms in a molecule
    title: has bonds
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    aliases:
    - adjacency matrix
    rank: 1000
    domain: Molecule
    alias: has_bonds
    owner: Macromolecule
    domain_of:
    - Molecule
    range: AtomicBond
    multivalued: true
  has_submolecules:
    name: has_submolecules
    description: Relation between a molecule and the molecules it is made from.
    title: has submolecules
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: has_part
    domain: Molecule
    alias: has_submolecules
    owner: Macromolecule
    domain_of:
    - Molecule
    range: Molecule
    multivalued: true
  has_atoms:
    name: has_atoms
    description: 'Relation between a molecule and the atoms it contains. Note that
      this is a shortcut relation: for granular representations go via atom occurrences'
    title: has atoms
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: has_part
    domain: Molecule
    alias: has_atoms
    owner: Macromolecule
    domain_of:
    - Molecule
    range: Atom
    multivalued: true
  is_organic:
    name: is_organic
    description: An organic molecule is a molecule composed of organic atoms (at least
      carbon, hydrogen, and optionally oxygen, phosphorus, nitrogen, sulfur) [SIO]
    title: is organic
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    close_mappings:
    - SIO:010072
    rank: 1000
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: is_organic
    owner: Macromolecule
    domain_of:
    - Molecule
    range: boolean
  inchi_atom_connections_sublayer:
    name: inchi_atom_connections_sublayer
    description: The atoms in the chemical formula (except for hydrogens) are numbered
      in sequence; this sublayer describes which atoms are connected by bonds to which
      other ones.
    title: inchi atom connections sublayer
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: inchi_sublayer_in_main_layer
    alias: inchi_atom_connections_sublayer
    owner: Macromolecule
    domain_of:
    - PolyatomicEntity
    - StandardInchiObject
    - EntityWithConnectivitySpecificied
    range: string
    required: false
    recommended: true
    pattern: ^c.*
  IUPAC_name:
    name: IUPAC_name
    title: IUPAC name
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    exact_mappings:
    - MI:2007
    rank: 1000
    is_a: information_property
    slot_uri: CHEMINF:000107
    alias: IUPAC_name
    owner: Macromolecule
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: string
  is_radical:
    name: is_radical
    title: is radical
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: is_radical
    owner: Macromolecule
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: boolean
  has_chemical_role:
    name: has_chemical_role
    title: has chemical role
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    alias: has_chemical_role
    owner: Macromolecule
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalRole
  inchi_string:
    name: inchi_string
    title: InChi
    todos:
    - declare this as a key once compound_key is introduced to linkml
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    see_also:
    - https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/questions/151072/can-cis-trans-isomers-have-same-inchi
    aliases:
    - InChi
    exact_mappings:
    - OntoRXN:hasInChi
    rank: 1000
    is_a: chemical_formula
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: inchi_string
    owner: Macromolecule
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalEncoding
  inchi_chemical_sublayer:
    name: inchi_chemical_sublayer
    annotations:
      inchi.index:
        tag: inchi.index
        value: 2
    description: The part of an InChI string that represents the chemical formula,
      occurring after the version string. E.g. C6H12O6 for glucose
    title: inchi chemical sublayer
    comments:
    - in the case of hydrates, the dot separates the formula of the compound from
      the water molecules. For example, CuSO₄·5H₂O represents copper(II) sulfate pentahydrate,
      indicating that there are five water molecules associated with each copper(II)
      sulfate unit in the crystal.
    - 'Salt Formulations: Dots can also be used to denote the proportions in which
      different components are combined to form a salt. For instance, "CaCl₂·2AgNO₃"
      would suggest a complex formed from one unit of calcium chloride and two units
      of silver nitrate, though this particular example is more illustrative than
      practical.'
    - 'Coordination Complexes: In coordination chemistry, dots can separate the metal
      complex from its counterions or ligands that are not directly bonded to the
      metal center. For example, "[Co(NH₃)₆]Cl₃" indicates a complex of cobalt with
      six ammonia ligands, and the three chloride ions are counterions. If written
      as "[Co(NH₃)₆]·3Cl", it would similarly denote the presence of three chloride
      ions associated with the complex, though this notation is less common'
    - 'Molecular Assemblies: For certain supramolecular structures or assemblies,
      dots might be used to indicate a non-covalent association of components. This
      usage is less common and more context-dependent'
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: inchi_sublayer_in_main_layer
    alias: inchi_chemical_sublayer
    owner: Macromolecule
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    - StandardInchiObject
    - EntityWithAtomsEnumerated
    range: string
    required: false
    recommended: true
    pattern: ^[A-Z0-9\.]+$
  smiles_string:
    name: smiles_string
    description: A string encoding of a molecular graph, no chiral or isotopic information.
      There are usually a large number of valid SMILES which represent a given structure.
      For example, CCO, OCC and C(O)C all specify the structure of ethanol.
    title: smiles string
    comments:
    - a problematic set of structures to describe using SMILES notation is those which
      cannot be easily described using molecular graphs (see “Limitations of molecular
      graph representations” section), such as organometallic compounds and ionic
      salts.
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: chemical_formula
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: smiles_string
    owner: Macromolecule
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalEncoding
  empirical_formula:
    name: empirical_formula
    description: A chemical formula where numbers denote relative proportion of atoms.
      E.g. CH2O for glucose
    title: empirical formula
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: chemical_formula
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: empirical_formula
    owner: Macromolecule
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalEncoding
  has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3:
    name: has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3
    description: Links different variants of the same chemical in different protonation
      states, where the target of this link is the (predicited) to be most common
      protonation state for this chemical at a pH of 7.3. This link may point to it's
      source. Connects an acid to the form that is stable at physiological pH (7.3).
      E.g. citric acid has physiological base citrate(3-)
    title: has physiologically stable form
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    see_also:
    - https://ftp.expasy.org/databases/rhea/tsv/chebi_pH7_3_mapping.tsv
    aliases:
    - protonation neutral form of
    - has Ph 7.3 mapping
    rank: 1000
    is_a: acid_form_of
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3
    owner: Macromolecule
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    inverse: major_microspecies_at_pH7_3_of
    range: ChemicalEntity
    multivalued: true
  molecular_mass:
    name: molecular_mass
    description: The sum of the relative atomic masses of the constituent atoms of
      a molecule.
    title: molecular mass
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    exact_mappings:
    - NCIT:C28272
    - FIX:0000270
    - chebi.property:mass
    rank: 1000
    is_a: molecular_property
    alias: molecular_mass
    owner: Macromolecule
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: float
    unit:
      ucum_code: u
  owl_subclass_of:
    name: owl_subclass_of
    description: 'Holds between C and P if C owl:subClassOf P. Note that in this model,
      most classes are metaclasses (see ''owl class''), where these metaclasses may
      represent *groupings* or specific countable elements or species. We provide
      two different sub-properties of subclass of for two cases: (1) subtype_of, which
      connects grouping classes (e.g. alkane is_a hydrocarbon; alpha-amino-acid is_a
      amino-acid), (2) classified_by, which connects a specific element to a grouping
      class (e.g. methane is_a hydrocarbon; iron is_a metal; serine is_a amino-acid)'
    title: owl subclass of
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    aliases:
    - is a
    exact_mappings:
    - rdfs:subClassOf
    narrow_mappings:
    - bo:family
    rank: 1000
    is_a: classification_relationship
    mixin: true
    domain: OwlClass
    alias: owl_subclass_of
    owner: Macromolecule
    domain_of:
    - OwlClass
    range: OwlClass
  id:
    name: id
    title: id
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    mappings:
    - schema:identifier
    rank: 1000
    is_a: information_property
    identifier: true
    alias: id
    owner: Macromolecule
    domain_of:
    - DomainEntity
    - GroupingClass
    - ChemicalGroupingClass
    range: string
    required: true
  name:
    name: name
    description: name of chemical entity. E.g. nickel, carbon-16
    title: name
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    close_mappings:
    - bo:symbol

    alias: name
    owner: Macromolecule

    - DomainEntity
    - GroupingClass

    range: string
  type:

    title: type
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    designates_type: true
    alias: type
    owner: Macromolecule
    domain_of:

      represent *groupings* or specific countable elements or species. We provide
      two different sub-properties of subclass of for two cases: (1) subtype_of, which

      amino-acid), (2) classified_by, which connects a specific element to a grouping
      class (e.g. methane is_a hydrocarbon; iron is_a metal; serine is_a amino-acid)'

docs.text:
name: Moiety
description: a named part of a molecule. In some instances moieties may be composed
  of yet smaller moieties and functional groups
title: moiety
from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
is_a: MolecularComponent
attributes:
  inchi_atom_connections_sublayer:
    name: inchi_atom_connections_sublayer
    description: The atoms in the chemical formula (except for hydrogens) are numbered
      in sequence; this sublayer describes which atoms are connected by bonds to which
      other ones.
    title: inchi atom connections sublayer
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: inchi_sublayer_in_main_layer
    alias: inchi_atom_connections_sublayer
    owner: Moiety
    domain_of:
    - PolyatomicEntity
    - StandardInchiObject
    - EntityWithConnectivitySpecificied
    range: string
    required: false
    recommended: true
    pattern: ^c.*
  IUPAC_name:
    name: IUPAC_name
    title: IUPAC name
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    exact_mappings:
    - MI:2007
    rank: 1000
    is_a: information_property
    slot_uri: CHEMINF:000107
    alias: IUPAC_name
    owner: Moiety
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: string
  is_radical:
    name: is_radical
    title: is radical
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: is_radical
    owner: Moiety
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: boolean
  has_chemical_role:
    name: has_chemical_role
    title: has chemical role
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    alias: has_chemical_role
    owner: Moiety
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalRole
  inchi_string:
    name: inchi_string
    title: InChi
    todos:
    - declare this as a key once compound_key is introduced to linkml
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    see_also:
    - https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/questions/151072/can-cis-trans-isomers-have-same-inchi
    aliases:
    - InChi
    exact_mappings:
    - OntoRXN:hasInChi
    rank: 1000
    is_a: chemical_formula
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: inchi_string
    owner: Moiety
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalEncoding
  inchi_chemical_sublayer:
    name: inchi_chemical_sublayer
    annotations:
      inchi.index:
        tag: inchi.index
        value: 2
    description: The part of an InChI string that represents the chemical formula,
      occurring after the version string. E.g. C6H12O6 for glucose
    title: inchi chemical sublayer
    comments:
    - in the case of hydrates, the dot separates the formula of the compound from
      the water molecules. For example, CuSO₄·5H₂O represents copper(II) sulfate pentahydrate,
      indicating that there are five water molecules associated with each copper(II)
      sulfate unit in the crystal.
    - 'Salt Formulations: Dots can also be used to denote the proportions in which
      different components are combined to form a salt. For instance, "CaCl₂·2AgNO₃"
      would suggest a complex formed from one unit of calcium chloride and two units
      of silver nitrate, though this particular example is more illustrative than
      practical.'
    - 'Coordination Complexes: In coordination chemistry, dots can separate the metal
      complex from its counterions or ligands that are not directly bonded to the
      metal center. For example, "[Co(NH₃)₆]Cl₃" indicates a complex of cobalt with
      six ammonia ligands, and the three chloride ions are counterions. If written
      as "[Co(NH₃)₆]·3Cl", it would similarly denote the presence of three chloride
      ions associated with the complex, though this notation is less common'
    - 'Molecular Assemblies: For certain supramolecular structures or assemblies,
      dots might be used to indicate a non-covalent association of components. This
      usage is less common and more context-dependent'
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: inchi_sublayer_in_main_layer
    alias: inchi_chemical_sublayer
    owner: Moiety
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    - StandardInchiObject
    - EntityWithAtomsEnumerated
    range: string
    required: false
    recommended: true
    pattern: ^[A-Z0-9\.]+$
  smiles_string:
    name: smiles_string
    description: A string encoding of a molecular graph, no chiral or isotopic information.
      There are usually a large number of valid SMILES which represent a given structure.
      For example, CCO, OCC and C(O)C all specify the structure of ethanol.
    title: smiles string
    comments:
    - a problematic set of structures to describe using SMILES notation is those which
      cannot be easily described using molecular graphs (see “Limitations of molecular
      graph representations” section), such as organometallic compounds and ionic
      salts.
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: chemical_formula
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: smiles_string
    owner: Moiety
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalEncoding
  empirical_formula:
    name: empirical_formula
    description: A chemical formula where numbers denote relative proportion of atoms.
      E.g. CH2O for glucose
    title: empirical formula
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: chemical_formula
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: empirical_formula
    owner: Moiety
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalEncoding
  has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3:
    name: has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3
    description: Links different variants of the same chemical in different protonation
      states, where the target of this link is the (predicited) to be most common
      protonation state for this chemical at a pH of 7.3. This link may point to it's
      source. Connects an acid to the form that is stable at physiological pH (7.3).
      E.g. citric acid has physiological base citrate(3-)
    title: has physiologically stable form
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    see_also:
    - https://ftp.expasy.org/databases/rhea/tsv/chebi_pH7_3_mapping.tsv
    aliases:
    - protonation neutral form of
    - has Ph 7.3 mapping
    rank: 1000
    is_a: acid_form_of
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3
    owner: Moiety
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    inverse: major_microspecies_at_pH7_3_of
    range: ChemicalEntity
    multivalued: true
  molecular_mass:
    name: molecular_mass
    description: The sum of the relative atomic masses of the constituent atoms of
      a molecule.
    title: molecular mass
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    exact_mappings:
    - NCIT:C28272
    - FIX:0000270
    - chebi.property:mass
    rank: 1000
    is_a: molecular_property
    alias: molecular_mass
    owner: Moiety
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: float
    unit:
      ucum_code: u
  owl_subclass_of:
    name: owl_subclass_of
    description: 'Holds between C and P if C owl:subClassOf P. Note that in this model,
      most classes are metaclasses (see ''owl class''), where these metaclasses may
      represent *groupings* or specific countable elements or species. We provide
      two different sub-properties of subclass of for two cases: (1) subtype_of, which
      connects grouping classes (e.g. alkane is_a hydrocarbon; alpha-amino-acid is_a
      amino-acid), (2) classified_by, which connects a specific element to a grouping
      class (e.g. methane is_a hydrocarbon; iron is_a metal; serine is_a amino-acid)'
    title: owl subclass of
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    aliases:
    - is a
    exact_mappings:
    - rdfs:subClassOf
    narrow_mappings:
    - bo:family
    rank: 1000
    is_a: classification_relationship
    mixin: true
    domain: OwlClass
    alias: owl_subclass_of
    owner: Moiety
    domain_of:
    - OwlClass
    range: OwlClass
  id:
    name: id
    title: id
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    mappings:
    - schema:identifier
    rank: 1000
    is_a: information_property
    identifier: true
    alias: id
    owner: Moiety
    domain_of:
    - DomainEntity
    - GroupingClass
    - ChemicalGroupingClass
    range: string
    required: true
  name:
    name: name
    description: name of chemical entity. E.g. nickel, carbon-16
    title: name
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    close_mappings:
    - bo:symbol
    rank: 1000
    is_a: information_property
    slot_uri: rdfs:label
    alias: name
    owner: Moiety
    domain_of:
    - DomainEntity
    - GroupingClass
    - Atom
    - AtomOccurrence
    range: string

    name: type
    title: type
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000

    name: conjugate_base_of
    description: 'connects the base form of an acid to an acid. Also connects the
      different charge states of the base. Example: the different charge states of
      lactate (CHEBI:24996) conjugate base of lactic acid (CHEBI:28358)'
    title: conjugate base of
    notes:
    - sometimes chebi hops over a state skipping an intermediate
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof

    alias: has_atoms
    owner: MolecularAnion
    domain_of:
    - Molecule
    range: Atom

  is_organic:

    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof

    - SIO:010072
    rank: 1000
    domain: ChemicalEntity

    owner: MolecularAnion

    - Molecule
    range: boolean
  inchi_atom_connections_sublayer:
    name: inchi_atom_connections_sublayer
    description: The atoms in the chemical formula (except for hydrogens) are numbered
      in sequence; this sublayer describes which atoms are connected by bonds to which

  has_chemical_role:
    name: has_chemical_role

    aliases:

    exact_mappings:

    rank: 1000
    is_a: chemical_formula
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: inchi_string
    owner: MolecularAnion
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalEncoding
  inchi_chemical_sublayer:
    name: inchi_chemical_sublayer
    annotations:
      inchi.index:
        tag: inchi.index
        value: 2
    description: The part of an InChI string that represents the chemical formula,
      occurring after the version string. E.g. C6H12O6 for glucose
    title: inchi chemical sublayer
    comments:
    - in the case of hydrates, the dot separates the formula of the compound from
      the water molecules. For example, CuSO₄·5H₂O represents copper(II) sulfate pentahydrate,
      indicating that there are five water molecules associated with each copper(II)
      sulfate unit in the crystal.
    - 'Salt Formulations: Dots can also be used to denote the proportions in which
      different components are combined to form a salt. For instance, "CaCl₂·2AgNO₃"
      would suggest a complex formed from one unit of calcium chloride and two units
      of silver nitrate, though this particular example is more illustrative than
      practical.'
    - 'Coordination Complexes: In coordination chemistry, dots can separate the metal
      complex from its counterions or ligands that are not directly bonded to the
      metal center. For example, "[Co(NH₃)₆]Cl₃" indicates a complex of cobalt with
      six ammonia ligands, and the three chloride ions are counterions. If written
      as "[Co(NH₃)₆]·3Cl", it would similarly denote the presence of three chloride
      ions associated with the complex, though this notation is less common'
    - 'Molecular Assemblies: For certain supramolecular structures or assemblies,
      dots might be used to indicate a non-covalent association of components. This
      usage is less common and more context-dependent'
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: inchi_sublayer_in_main_layer
    alias: inchi_chemical_sublayer
    owner: MolecularAnion
    domain_of:

    - StandardInchiObject
    - EntityWithAtomsEnumerated
    range: string
    required: false
    recommended: true
    pattern: ^[A-Z0-9\.]+$
  smiles_string:
    name: smiles_string
    description: A string encoding of a molecular graph, no chiral or isotopic information.
      There are usually a large number of valid SMILES which represent a given structure.
      For example, CCO, OCC and C(O)C all specify the structure of ethanol.
    title: smiles string
    comments:
    - a problematic set of structures to describe using SMILES notation is those which
      cannot be easily described using molecular graphs (see “Limitations of molecular
      graph representations” section), such as organometallic compounds and ionic
      salts.

    domain: ChemicalEntity

    range: ChemicalEncoding
  empirical_formula:

      E.g. CH2O for glucose
    title: empirical formula

    name: has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3
    description: Links different variants of the same chemical in different protonation
      states, where the target of this link is the (predicited) to be most common
      protonation state for this chemical at a pH of 7.3. This link may point to it's
      source. Connects an acid to the form that is stable at physiological pH (7.3).
      E.g. citric acid has physiological base citrate(3-)
    title: has physiologically stable form
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    see_also:
    - https://ftp.expasy.org/databases/rhea/tsv/chebi_pH7_3_mapping.tsv
    aliases:
    - protonation neutral form of
    - has Ph 7.3 mapping
    rank: 1000
    is_a: acid_form_of
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3
    owner: MolecularAnion
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    inverse: major_microspecies_at_pH7_3_of
    range: ChemicalEntity
    multivalued: true
  molecular_mass:
    name: molecular_mass
    description: The sum of the relative atomic masses of the constituent atoms of
      a molecule.
    title: molecular mass
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    exact_mappings:
    - NCIT:C28272
    - FIX:0000270
    - chebi.property:mass
    rank: 1000

  owl_subclass_of:
    name: owl_subclass_of
    description: 'Holds between C and P if C owl:subClassOf P. Note that in this model,
      most classes are metaclasses (see ''owl class''), where these metaclasses may
      represent *groupings* or specific countable elements or species. We provide
      two different sub-properties of subclass of for two cases: (1) subtype_of, which
      connects grouping classes (e.g. alkane is_a hydrocarbon; alpha-amino-acid is_a
      amino-acid), (2) classified_by, which connects a specific element to a grouping
      class (e.g. methane is_a hydrocarbon; iron is_a metal; serine is_a amino-acid)'
    title: owl subclass of
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof

docs.title: Class: molecular cation (MolecularCation)
docs.text:
A polyatomic ion that is positive

URI: chemrof:MolecularCation

 classDiagram
    class MolecularCation
    click MolecularCation href "../MolecularCation"
      CationState <|-- MolecularCation
        click CationState href "../CationState"
      PolyatomicIon <|-- MolecularCation
        click PolyatomicIon href "../PolyatomicIon"

      MolecularCation : bronsted_acid_base_role





        MolecularCation --> "0..1" BronstedAcidBaseRoleEnum : bronsted_acid_base_role
        click BronstedAcidBaseRoleEnum href "../BronstedAcidBaseRoleEnum"



      MolecularCation : conjugate_acid_of





        MolecularCation --> "0..1" DomainEntity : conjugate_acid_of
        click DomainEntity href "../DomainEntity"



      MolecularCation : conjugate_base_of





        MolecularCation --> "0..1" DomainEntity : conjugate_base_of
        click DomainEntity href "../DomainEntity"



      MolecularCation : elemental_charge

      MolecularCation : empirical_formula

      MolecularCation : has_atom_occurrences





        MolecularCation --> "2..*" AtomOccurrence : has_atom_occurrences
        click AtomOccurrence href "../AtomOccurrence"



      MolecularCation : has_atoms





        MolecularCation --> "*" Atom : has_atoms
        click Atom href "../Atom"



      MolecularCation : has_bonds





        MolecularCation --> "*" AtomicBond : has_bonds
        click AtomicBond href "../AtomicBond"



      MolecularCation : has_chemical_role





        MolecularCation --> "0..1" ChemicalRole : has_chemical_role
        click ChemicalRole href "../ChemicalRole"



      MolecularCation : has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3





        MolecularCation --> "*" ChemicalEntity : has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3
        click ChemicalEntity href "../ChemicalEntity"



      MolecularCation : has_submolecules





        MolecularCation --> "*" Molecule : has_submolecules
        click Molecule href "../Molecule"



      MolecularCation : id

      MolecularCation : inchi_atom_connections_sublayer

      MolecularCation : inchi_chemical_sublayer

      MolecularCation : inchi_string

      MolecularCation : is_organic

      MolecularCation : is_radical

      MolecularCation : IUPAC_name

      MolecularCation : molecular_mass

      MolecularCation : name

      MolecularCation : owl_subclass_of





        MolecularCation --> "0..1" OwlClass : owl_subclass_of
        click OwlClass href "../OwlClass"



      MolecularCation : smiles_string

      MolecularCation : type

docs.title: Class: molecular complex (MolecularComplex)
docs.text:
A molecular complex is a chemical complex composed of at least one weakly interacting molecule.[SIO] Examples: chromosome, double-standed DNA, protein-containing macromolecular complex

URI: chemrof:MolecularComplex

 classDiagram
    class MolecularComplex
    click MolecularComplex href "../MolecularComplex"
      PreciseChemicalMixture <|-- MolecularComplex
        click PreciseChemicalMixture href "../PreciseChemicalMixture"


      MolecularComplex <|-- SupramolecularPolymer
        click SupramolecularPolymer href "../SupramolecularPolymer"


      MolecularComplex : empirical_formula

      MolecularComplex : has_chemical_role





        MolecularComplex --> "0..1" ChemicalRole : has_chemical_role
        click ChemicalRole href "../ChemicalRole"



      MolecularComplex : has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3





        MolecularComplex --> "*" ChemicalEntity : has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3
        click ChemicalEntity href "../ChemicalEntity"



      MolecularComplex : id

      MolecularComplex : inchi_atom_connections_sublayer

      MolecularComplex : inchi_chemical_sublayer

      MolecularComplex : inchi_string

      MolecularComplex : is_radical

      MolecularComplex : IUPAC_name

      MolecularComplex : molecular_mass

      MolecularComplex : name

      MolecularComplex : owl_subclass_of





        MolecularComplex --> "0..1" OwlClass : owl_subclass_of
        click OwlClass href "../OwlClass"



      MolecularComplex : smiles_string

      MolecularComplex : type

docs.title: Aliases
docs.text:
• poly molecular composite entity
  • complex of molecular entities
  • molecule complex

docs.title: Comments
docs.text:
• In bioptop, molecule complex is a sibling of structured biological entity under poly molecular composite entity
  • In SIO, molecular complex is an only child of chemical complex, which is under chemical substance. chemical complex is defined as A chemical complex is a chemical substance composed of a weakly connected molecules and ions in a known stoichiometry.

docs.text: • from schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof

description: 'A molecular complex is a chemical complex composed of at least one weakly

comments:

attributes:
  inchi_atom_connections_sublayer:
    name: inchi_atom_connections_sublayer
    description: The atoms in the chemical formula (except for hydrogens) are numbered
      in sequence; this sublayer describes which atoms are connected by bonds to which
      other ones.
    title: inchi atom connections sublayer
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof

    alias: inchi_atom_connections_sublayer
    owner: MolecularComplex

    - EntityWithConnectivitySpecificied
    range: string
    required: false
    recommended: true
    pattern: ^c.*
  IUPAC_name:
    name: IUPAC_name
    title: IUPAC name
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    exact_mappings:
    - MI:2007
    rank: 1000
    is_a: information_property
    slot_uri: CHEMINF:000107
    alias: IUPAC_name
    owner: MolecularComplex
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: string
  is_radical:
    name: is_radical
    title: is radical
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: is_radical
    owner: MolecularComplex
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: boolean
  has_chemical_role:
    name: has_chemical_role
    title: has chemical role
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    alias: has_chemical_role
    owner: MolecularComplex
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalRole
  inchi_string:
    name: inchi_string
    title: InChi
    todos:
    - declare this as a key once compound_key is introduced to linkml
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    see_also:
    - https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/questions/151072/can-cis-trans-isomers-have-same-inchi
    aliases:
    - InChi
    exact_mappings:
    - OntoRXN:hasInChi
    rank: 1000
    is_a: chemical_formula
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: inchi_string
    owner: MolecularComplex
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalEncoding
  inchi_chemical_sublayer:
    name: inchi_chemical_sublayer
    annotations:
      inchi.index:
        tag: inchi.index
        value: 2
    description: The part of an InChI string that represents the chemical formula,
      occurring after the version string. E.g. C6H12O6 for glucose
    title: inchi chemical sublayer
    comments:
    - in the case of hydrates, the dot separates the formula of the compound from
      the water molecules. For example, CuSO₄·5H₂O represents copper(II) sulfate pentahydrate,
      indicating that there are five water molecules associated with each copper(II)
      sulfate unit in the crystal.
    - 'Salt Formulations: Dots can also be used to denote the proportions in which
      different components are combined to form a salt. For instance, "CaCl₂·2AgNO₃"
      would suggest a complex formed from one unit of calcium chloride and two units
      of silver nitrate, though this particular example is more illustrative than
      practical.'
    - 'Coordination Complexes: In coordination chemistry, dots can separate the metal
      complex from its counterions or ligands that are not directly bonded to the
      metal center. For example, "[Co(NH₃)₆]Cl₃" indicates a complex of cobalt with
      six ammonia ligands, and the three chloride ions are counterions. If written
      as "[Co(NH₃)₆]·3Cl", it would similarly denote the presence of three chloride
      ions associated with the complex, though this notation is less common'
    - 'Molecular Assemblies: For certain supramolecular structures or assemblies,
      dots might be used to indicate a non-covalent association of components. This
      usage is less common and more context-dependent'
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: inchi_sublayer_in_main_layer
    alias: inchi_chemical_sublayer
    owner: MolecularComplex
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    - StandardInchiObject
    - EntityWithAtomsEnumerated
    range: string
    required: false
    recommended: true
    pattern: ^[A-Z0-9\.]+$
  smiles_string:
    name: smiles_string
    description: A string encoding of a molecular graph, no chiral or isotopic information.
      There are usually a large number of valid SMILES which represent a given structure.
      For example, CCO, OCC and C(O)C all specify the structure of ethanol.
    title: smiles string
    comments:
    - a problematic set of structures to describe using SMILES notation is those which
      cannot be easily described using molecular graphs (see “Limitations of molecular
      graph representations” section), such as organometallic compounds and ionic
      salts.
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: chemical_formula
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: smiles_string
    owner: MolecularComplex
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalEncoding
  empirical_formula:
    name: empirical_formula
    description: A chemical formula where numbers denote relative proportion of atoms.
      E.g. CH2O for glucose
    title: empirical formula
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: chemical_formula
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: empirical_formula
    owner: MolecularComplex
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalEncoding
  has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3:
    name: has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3
    description: Links different variants of the same chemical in different protonation
      states, where the target of this link is the (predicited) to be most common
      protonation state for this chemical at a pH of 7.3. This link may point to it's
      source. Connects an acid to the form that is stable at physiological pH (7.3).
      E.g. citric acid has physiological base citrate(3-)
    title: has physiologically stable form
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    see_also:
    - https://ftp.expasy.org/databases/rhea/tsv/chebi_pH7_3_mapping.tsv
    aliases:
    - protonation neutral form of
    - has Ph 7.3 mapping
    rank: 1000
    is_a: acid_form_of
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3
    owner: MolecularComplex
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    inverse: major_microspecies_at_pH7_3_of
    range: ChemicalEntity
    multivalued: true
  molecular_mass:
    name: molecular_mass
    description: The sum of the relative atomic masses of the constituent atoms of
      a molecule.
    title: molecular mass
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    exact_mappings:

    title: owl subclass of
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof

      states, where the target of this link is the (predicited) to be most common
      protonation state for this chemical at a pH of 7.3. This link may point to it's
      source. Connects an acid to the form that is stable at physiological pH (7.3).
      E.g. citric acid has physiological base citrate(3-)
    title: has physiologically stable form
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    see_also:
    - https://ftp.expasy.org/databases/rhea/tsv/chebi_pH7_3_mapping.tsv
    aliases:

    - has Ph 7.3 mapping

    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: is_radical
    owner: MolecularSpecies
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: boolean
  has_chemical_role:
    name: has_chemical_role
    title: has chemical role
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    alias: has_chemical_role
    owner: MolecularSpecies
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalRole
  inchi_string:
    name: inchi_string
    title: InChi
    todos:
    - declare this as a key once compound_key is introduced to linkml
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    see_also:
    - https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/questions/151072/can-cis-trans-isomers-have-same-inchi
    aliases:
    - InChi
    exact_mappings:
    - OntoRXN:hasInChi
    rank: 1000
    is_a: chemical_formula
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: inchi_string
    owner: MolecularSpecies
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalEncoding
  inchi_chemical_sublayer:
    name: inchi_chemical_sublayer
    annotations:
      inchi.index:
        tag: inchi.index
        value: 2
    description: The part of an InChI string that represents the chemical formula,
      occurring after the version string. E.g. C6H12O6 for glucose
    title: inchi chemical sublayer
    comments:
    - in the case of hydrates, the dot separates the formula of the compound from
      the water molecules. For example, CuSO₄·5H₂O represents copper(II) sulfate pentahydrate,
      indicating that there are five water molecules associated with each copper(II)
      sulfate unit in the crystal.
    - 'Salt Formulations: Dots can also be used to denote the proportions in which
      different components are combined to form a salt. For instance, "CaCl₂·2AgNO₃"
      would suggest a complex formed from one unit of calcium chloride and two units
      of silver nitrate, though this particular example is more illustrative than
      practical.'
    - 'Coordination Complexes: In coordination chemistry, dots can separate the metal
      complex from its counterions or ligands that are not directly bonded to the
      metal center. For example, "[Co(NH₃)₆]Cl₃" indicates a complex of cobalt with
      six ammonia ligands, and the three chloride ions are counterions. If written
      as "[Co(NH₃)₆]·3Cl", it would similarly denote the presence of three chloride
      ions associated with the complex, though this notation is less common'
    - 'Molecular Assemblies: For certain supramolecular structures or assemblies,
      dots might be used to indicate a non-covalent association of components. This
      usage is less common and more context-dependent'
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: inchi_sublayer_in_main_layer
    alias: inchi_chemical_sublayer
    owner: MolecularSpecies
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    - StandardInchiObject
    - EntityWithAtomsEnumerated
    range: string
    required: false
    recommended: true
    pattern: ^[A-Z0-9\.]+$
  smiles_string:
    name: smiles_string
    description: A string encoding of a molecular graph, no chiral or isotopic information.
      There are usually a large number of valid SMILES which represent a given structure.
      For example, CCO, OCC and C(O)C all specify the structure of ethanol.
    title: smiles string
    comments:
    - a problematic set of structures to describe using SMILES notation is those which
      cannot be easily described using molecular graphs (see “Limitations of molecular
      graph representations” section), such as organometallic compounds and ionic
      salts.
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: chemical_formula
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: smiles_string
    owner: MolecularSpecies
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalEncoding
  empirical_formula:
    name: empirical_formula
    description: A chemical formula where numbers denote relative proportion of atoms.
      E.g. CH2O for glucose
    title: empirical formula
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: chemical_formula
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: empirical_formula
    owner: MolecularSpecies
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalEncoding
  has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3:
    name: has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3
    description: Links different variants of the same chemical in different protonation
      states, where the target of this link is the (predicited) to be most common
      protonation state for this chemical at a pH of 7.3. This link may point to it's
      source. Connects an acid to the form that is stable at physiological pH (7.3).
      E.g. citric acid has physiological base citrate(3-)
    title: has physiologically stable form
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    see_also:
    - https://ftp.expasy.org/databases/rhea/tsv/chebi_pH7_3_mapping.tsv
    aliases:
    - protonation neutral form of
    - has Ph 7.3 mapping
    rank: 1000
    is_a: acid_form_of
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3
    owner: MolecularSpecies
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    inverse: major_microspecies_at_pH7_3_of
    range: ChemicalEntity
    multivalued: true
  molecular_mass:
    name: molecular_mass
    description: The sum of the relative atomic masses of the constituent atoms of
      a molecule.
    title: molecular mass
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    exact_mappings:
    - NCIT:C28272
    - FIX:0000270
    - chebi.property:mass
    rank: 1000
    is_a: molecular_property
    alias: molecular_mass
    owner: MolecularSpecies
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: float
    unit:
      ucum_code: u
  owl_subclass_of:
    name: owl_subclass_of
    description: 'Holds between C and P if C owl:subClassOf P. Note that in this model,
      most classes are metaclasses (see ''owl class''), where these metaclasses may
      represent *groupings* or specific countable elements or species. We provide
      two different sub-properties of subclass of for two cases: (1) subtype_of, which
      connects grouping classes (e.g. alkane is_a hydrocarbon; alpha-amino-acid is_a
      amino-acid), (2) classified_by, which connects a specific element to a grouping
      class (e.g. methane is_a hydrocarbon; iron is_a metal; serine is_a amino-acid)'
    title: owl subclass of
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    aliases:
    - is a
    exact_mappings:
    - rdfs:subClassOf
    narrow_mappings:
    - bo:family
    rank: 1000
    is_a: classification_relationship
    mixin: true
    domain: OwlClass
    alias: owl_subclass_of
    owner: MolecularSpecies
    domain_of:
    - OwlClass
    range: OwlClass
  id:
    name: id
    title: id
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    mappings:
    - schema:identifier
    rank: 1000
    is_a: information_property
    identifier: true

    domain_of:
    - DomainEntity

    range: string

docs.title: Class: molecule (Molecule)
docs.text:
A chemical entity that consists of two or more atoms where all atoms are connected via covalent bonds.

URI: chemrof:Molecule

 classDiagram
    class Molecule
    click Molecule href "../Molecule"
      FullyCovalentlyBonded <|-- Molecule
        click FullyCovalentlyBonded href "../FullyCovalentlyBonded"
      PolyatomicEntity <|-- Molecule
        click PolyatomicEntity href "../PolyatomicEntity"


      Molecule <|-- SmallMolecule
        click SmallMolecule href "../SmallMolecule"
      Molecule <|-- Macromolecule
        click Macromolecule href "../Macromolecule"
      Molecule <|-- NaturalProduct
        click NaturalProduct href "../NaturalProduct"
      Molecule <|-- MolecularSpecies
        click MolecularSpecies href "../MolecularSpecies"
      Molecule <|-- NonSpeciesMolecule
        click NonSpeciesMolecule href "../NonSpeciesMolecule"
      Molecule <|-- MoleculeByChargeState
        click MoleculeByChargeState href "../MoleculeByChargeState"
      Molecule <|-- Ester
        click Ester href "../Ester"
      Molecule <|-- Stereoisomer
        click Stereoisomer href "../Stereoisomer"
      Molecule <|-- Allotrope
        click Allotrope href "../Allotrope"


      Molecule : empirical_formula

      Molecule : has_atom_occurrences





        Molecule --> "2..*" AtomOccurrence : has_atom_occurrences
        click AtomOccurrence href "../AtomOccurrence"



      Molecule : has_atoms





        Molecule --> "*" Atom : has_atoms
        click Atom href "../Atom"



      Molecule : has_bonds





        Molecule --> "*" AtomicBond : has_bonds
        click AtomicBond href "../AtomicBond"



      Molecule : has_chemical_role





        Molecule --> "0..1" ChemicalRole : has_chemical_role
        click ChemicalRole href "../ChemicalRole"



      Molecule : has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3





        Molecule --> "*" ChemicalEntity : has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3
        click ChemicalEntity href "../ChemicalEntity"



      Molecule : has_submolecules





        Molecule --> "*" Molecule : has_submolecules
        click Molecule href "../Molecule"



      Molecule : id

      Molecule : inchi_atom_connections_sublayer

      Molecule : inchi_chemical_sublayer

      Molecule : inchi_string

      Molecule : is_organic

      Molecule : is_radical

      Molecule : IUPAC_name

      Molecule : molecular_mass

      Molecule : name

      Molecule : owl_subclass_of





        Molecule --> "0..1" OwlClass : owl_subclass_of
        click OwlClass href "../OwlClass"



      Molecule : smiles_string

      Molecule : type

docs.title: Direct
docs.text:
name: Molecule
description: A chemical entity that consists of two or more atoms where all atoms
  are connected via covalent bonds.
title: molecule
examples:
- value: dioxygen
- value: cysteine
- value: phosphene
from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
aliases:
- molecular entity
- monomolecular entity
mappings:
- COB:0000013
exact_mappings:
- SIO:011125
- biotop:MonoMolecularEntity
- gc:Molecule
is_a: PolyatomicEntity
mixins:
- FullyCovalentlyBonded
slots:
- has_atom_occurrences
- has_bonds
- has_submolecules
- has_atoms
- is_organic
slot_usage:
  has_atom_occurrences:
    name: has_atom_occurrences
    minimum_cardinality: 2
  has_bonds:
    name: has_bonds
    description: The set of all bonds connecting atoms in a molecule
    aliases:
    - adjacency matrix
  has_part:
    name: has_part
    minimum_value: 1

docs.text:
name: Molecule
description: A chemical entity that consists of two or more atoms where all atoms
  are connected via covalent bonds.
title: molecule
examples:

from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof

- biotop:MonoMolecularEntity

is_a: PolyatomicEntity

- FullyCovalentlyBonded
slot_usage:
  has_atom_occurrences:
    name: has_atom_occurrences
    minimum_cardinality: 2
  has_bonds:
    name: has_bonds
    description: The set of all bonds connecting atoms in a molecule
    aliases:
    - adjacency matrix
  has_part:

attributes:
  has_atom_occurrences:
    name: has_atom_occurrences
    description: An individuated atom in the context of a chemical structure.
    title: has atom occurrences
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    alias: has_atom_occurrences
    owner: Molecule
    domain_of:
    - Molecule
    range: AtomOccurrence
    multivalued: true
    inlined: true
    inlined_as_list: true
    minimum_cardinality: 2
  has_bonds:
    name: has_bonds
    description: The set of all bonds connecting atoms in a molecule
    title: has bonds
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    aliases:
    - adjacency matrix
    rank: 1000
    domain: Molecule
    alias: has_bonds
    owner: Molecule
    domain_of:
    - Molecule
    range: AtomicBond
    multivalued: true
  has_submolecules:
    name: has_submolecules
    description: Relation between a molecule and the molecules it is made from.
    title: has submolecules
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: has_part
    domain: Molecule
    alias: has_submolecules
    owner: Molecule
    domain_of:
    - Molecule
    range: Molecule
    multivalued: true
  has_atoms:
    name: has_atoms
    description: 'Relation between a molecule and the atoms it contains. Note that
      this is a shortcut relation: for granular representations go via atom occurrences'
    title: has atoms
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: has_part
    domain: Molecule
    alias: has_atoms
    owner: Molecule
    domain_of:
    - Molecule
    range: Atom
    multivalued: true
  is_organic:
    name: is_organic
    description: An organic molecule is a molecule composed of organic atoms (at least
      carbon, hydrogen, and optionally oxygen, phosphorus, nitrogen, sulfur) [SIO]
    title: is organic
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    close_mappings:
    - SIO:010072
    rank: 1000
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: is_organic
    owner: Molecule
    domain_of:
    - Molecule
    range: boolean
  inchi_atom_connections_sublayer:
    name: inchi_atom_connections_sublayer
    description: The atoms in the chemical formula (except for hydrogens) are numbered
      in sequence; this sublayer describes which atoms are connected by bonds to which
      other ones.
    title: inchi atom connections sublayer
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: inchi_sublayer_in_main_layer
    alias: inchi_atom_connections_sublayer
    owner: Molecule
    domain_of:
    - PolyatomicEntity
    - StandardInchiObject
    - EntityWithConnectivitySpecificied
    range: string
    required: false
    recommended: true
    pattern: ^c.*
  IUPAC_name:
    name: IUPAC_name
    title: IUPAC name
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    exact_mappings:
    - MI:2007
    rank: 1000
    is_a: information_property
    slot_uri: CHEMINF:000107
    alias: IUPAC_name
    owner: Molecule
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: string
  is_radical:
    name: is_radical
    title: is radical
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: is_radical
    owner: Molecule
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: boolean
  has_chemical_role:
    name: has_chemical_role
    title: has chemical role
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    alias: has_chemical_role
    owner: Molecule
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalRole
  inchi_string:
    name: inchi_string
    title: InChi
    todos:
    - declare this as a key once compound_key is introduced to linkml
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    see_also:
    - https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/questions/151072/can-cis-trans-isomers-have-same-inchi
    aliases:
    - InChi
    exact_mappings:
    - OntoRXN:hasInChi
    rank: 1000
    is_a: chemical_formula
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: inchi_string
    owner: Molecule
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalEncoding
  inchi_chemical_sublayer:
    name: inchi_chemical_sublayer
    annotations:
      inchi.index:
        tag: inchi.index
        value: 2
    description: The part of an InChI string that represents the chemical formula,
      occurring after the version string. E.g. C6H12O6 for glucose
    title: inchi chemical sublayer
    comments:
    - in the case of hydrates, the dot separates the formula of the compound from
      the water molecules. For example, CuSO₄·5H₂O represents copper(II) sulfate pentahydrate,
      indicating that there are five water molecules associated with each copper(II)
      sulfate unit in the crystal.
    - 'Salt Formulations: Dots can also be used to denote the proportions in which
      different components are combined to form a salt. For instance, "CaCl₂·2AgNO₃"
      would suggest a complex formed from one unit of calcium chloride and two units
      of silver nitrate, though this particular example is more illustrative than
      practical.'
    - 'Coordination Complexes: In coordination chemistry, dots can separate the metal
      complex from its counterions or ligands that are not directly bonded to the
      metal center. For example, "[Co(NH₃)₆]Cl₃" indicates a complex of cobalt with
      six ammonia ligands, and the three chloride ions are counterions. If written
      as "[Co(NH₃)₆]·3Cl", it would similarly denote the presence of three chloride
      ions associated with the complex, though this notation is less common'
    - 'Molecular Assemblies: For certain supramolecular structures or assemblies,
      dots might be used to indicate a non-covalent association of components. This
      usage is less common and more context-dependent'
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: inchi_sublayer_in_main_layer
    alias: inchi_chemical_sublayer
    owner: Molecule
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    - StandardInchiObject
    - EntityWithAtomsEnumerated
    range: string
    required: false
    recommended: true
    pattern: ^[A-Z0-9\.]+$
  smiles_string:
    name: smiles_string
    description: A string encoding of a molecular graph, no chiral or isotopic information.
      There are usually a large number of valid SMILES which represent a given structure.
      For example, CCO, OCC and C(O)C all specify the structure of ethanol.
    title: smiles string
    comments:
    - a problematic set of structures to describe using SMILES notation is those which
      cannot be easily described using molecular graphs (see “Limitations of molecular
      graph representations” section), such as organometallic compounds and ionic
      salts.
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: chemical_formula
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: smiles_string
    owner: Molecule
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalEncoding
  empirical_formula:
    name: empirical_formula
    description: A chemical formula where numbers denote relative proportion of atoms.
      E.g. CH2O for glucose
    title: empirical formula
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: chemical_formula
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: empirical_formula
    owner: Molecule
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalEncoding
  has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3:
    name: has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3
    description: Links different variants of the same chemical in different protonation
      states, where the target of this link is the (predicited) to be most common
      protonation state for this chemical at a pH of 7.3. This link may point to it's
      source. Connects an acid to the form that is stable at physiological pH (7.3).
      E.g. citric acid has physiological base citrate(3-)
    title: has physiologically stable form
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    see_also:
    - https://ftp.expasy.org/databases/rhea/tsv/chebi_pH7_3_mapping.tsv
    aliases:
    - protonation neutral form of
    - has Ph 7.3 mapping
    rank: 1000
    is_a: acid_form_of
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3
    owner: Molecule
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    inverse: major_microspecies_at_pH7_3_of
    range: ChemicalEntity
    multivalued: true
  molecular_mass:
    name: molecular_mass
    description: The sum of the relative atomic masses of the constituent atoms of
      a molecule.
    title: molecular mass
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    exact_mappings:
    - NCIT:C28272
    - FIX:0000270
    - chebi.property:mass
    rank: 1000
    is_a: molecular_property
    alias: molecular_mass
    owner: Molecule
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: float
    unit:
      ucum_code: u
  owl_subclass_of:
    name: owl_subclass_of
    description: 'Holds between C and P if C owl:subClassOf P. Note that in this model,
      most classes are metaclasses (see ''owl class''), where these metaclasses may
      represent *groupings* or specific countable elements or species. We provide
      two different sub-properties of subclass of for two cases: (1) subtype_of, which
      connects grouping classes (e.g. alkane is_a hydrocarbon; alpha-amino-acid is_a
      amino-acid), (2) classified_by, which connects a specific element to a grouping
      class (e.g. methane is_a hydrocarbon; iron is_a metal; serine is_a amino-acid)'
    title: owl subclass of
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    aliases:
    - is a
    exact_mappings:
    - rdfs:subClassOf
    narrow_mappings:
    - bo:family
    rank: 1000
    is_a: classification_relationship
    mixin: true
    domain: OwlClass
    alias: owl_subclass_of
    owner: Molecule
    domain_of:
    - OwlClass
    range: OwlClass
  id:
    name: id
    title: id
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    mappings:
    - schema:identifier
    rank: 1000
    is_a: information_property
    identifier: true
    alias: id
    owner: Molecule
    domain_of:
    - DomainEntity
    - GroupingClass
    - ChemicalGroupingClass
    range: string
    required: true
  name:
    name: name
    description: name of chemical entity. E.g. nickel, carbon-16
    title: name
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    close_mappings:
    - bo:symbol
    rank: 1000
    is_a: information_property
    slot_uri: rdfs:label
    alias: name
    owner: Molecule
    domain_of:
    - DomainEntity
    - GroupingClass
    - Atom
    - AtomOccurrence
    range: string
  type:
    name: type
    title: type
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    designates_type: true
    alias: type
    owner: Molecule
    domain_of:
    - DomainEntity
    range: uriorcurie

docs.title: Class: molecule by charge state (MoleculeByChargeState)
docs.text:
A molecule that has a charge state specified

  • NOTE: this is an abstract class and should not be instantiated directly

URI: chemrof:MoleculeByChargeState

 classDiagram
    class MoleculeByChargeState
    click MoleculeByChargeState href "../MoleculeByChargeState"
      Molecule <|-- MoleculeByChargeState
        click Molecule href "../Molecule"


      MoleculeByChargeState <|-- PolyatomicIon
        click PolyatomicIon href "../PolyatomicIon"
      MoleculeByChargeState <|-- NetUnchargedMolecule
        click NetUnchargedMolecule href "../NetUnchargedMolecule"

      MoleculeByChargeState : id

      inchi.index:
        tag: inchi.index
        value: 2
    description: The part of an InChI string that represents the chemical formula,
      occurring after the version string. E.g. C6H12O6 for glucose
    title: inchi chemical sublayer
    comments:
    - in the case of hydrates, the dot separates the formula of the compound from
      the water molecules. For example, CuSO₄·5H₂O represents copper(II) sulfate pentahydrate,
      indicating that there are five water molecules associated with each copper(II)
      sulfate unit in the crystal.
    - 'Salt Formulations: Dots can also be used to denote the proportions in which
      different components are combined to form a salt. For instance, "CaCl₂·2AgNO₃"
      would suggest a complex formed from one unit of calcium chloride and two units
      of silver nitrate, though this particular example is more illustrative than
      practical.'
    - 'Coordination Complexes: In coordination chemistry, dots can separate the metal
      complex from its counterions or ligands that are not directly bonded to the
      metal center. For example, "[Co(NH₃)₆]Cl₃" indicates a complex of cobalt with
      six ammonia ligands, and the three chloride ions are counterions. If written
      as "[Co(NH₃)₆]·3Cl", it would similarly denote the presence of three chloride
      ions associated with the complex, though this notation is less common'
    - 'Molecular Assemblies: For certain supramolecular structures or assemblies,
      dots might be used to indicate a non-covalent association of components. This
      usage is less common and more context-dependent'
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: inchi_sublayer_in_main_layer
    alias: inchi_chemical_sublayer
    owner: MoleculeByChargeState
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    - StandardInchiObject
    - EntityWithAtomsEnumerated
    range: string
    required: false
    recommended: true
    pattern: ^[A-Z0-9\.]+$
  smiles_string:
    name: smiles_string
    description: A string encoding of a molecular graph, no chiral or isotopic information.
      There are usually a large number of valid SMILES which represent a given structure.
      For example, CCO, OCC and C(O)C all specify the structure of ethanol.
    title: smiles string
    comments:
    - a problematic set of structures to describe using SMILES notation is those which
      cannot be easily described using molecular graphs (see “Limitations of molecular
      graph representations” section), such as organometallic compounds and ionic
      salts.
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: chemical_formula
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: smiles_string
    owner: MoleculeByChargeState
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalEncoding
  empirical_formula:
    name: empirical_formula
    description: A chemical formula where numbers denote relative proportion of atoms.
      E.g. CH2O for glucose
    title: empirical formula
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: chemical_formula
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: empirical_formula
    owner: MoleculeByChargeState
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalEncoding
  has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3:
    name: has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3
    description: Links different variants of the same chemical in different protonation
      states, where the target of this link is the (predicited) to be most common
      protonation state for this chemical at a pH of 7.3. This link may point to it's
      source. Connects an acid to the form that is stable at physiological pH (7.3).
      E.g. citric acid has physiological base citrate(3-)
    title: has physiologically stable form
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    see_also:
    - https://ftp.expasy.org/databases/rhea/tsv/chebi_pH7_3_mapping.tsv
    aliases:
    - protonation neutral form of
    - has Ph 7.3 mapping
    rank: 1000
    is_a: acid_form_of
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3
    owner: MoleculeByChargeState
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    inverse: major_microspecies_at_pH7_3_of
    range: ChemicalEntity
    multivalued: true
  molecular_mass:
    name: molecular_mass
    description: The sum of the relative atomic masses of the constituent atoms of
      a molecule.
    title: molecular mass
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    exact_mappings:
    - NCIT:C28272
    - FIX:0000270
    - chebi.property:mass
    rank: 1000
    is_a: molecular_property
    alias: molecular_mass
    owner: MoleculeByChargeState
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: float
    unit:
      ucum_code: u
  owl_subclass_of:
    name: owl_subclass_of
    description: 'Holds between C and P if C owl:subClassOf P. Note that in this model,
      most classes are metaclasses (see ''owl class''), where these metaclasses may
      represent *groupings* or specific countable elements or species. We provide
      two different sub-properties of subclass of for two cases: (1) subtype_of, which
      connects grouping classes (e.g. alkane is_a hydrocarbon; alpha-amino-acid is_a
      amino-acid), (2) classified_by, which connects a specific element to a grouping
      class (e.g. methane is_a hydrocarbon; iron is_a metal; serine is_a amino-acid)'
    title: owl subclass of
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    aliases:
    - is a
    exact_mappings:
    - rdfs:subClassOf
    narrow_mappings:
    - bo:family
    rank: 1000

    mixin: true
    domain: OwlClass
    alias: owl_subclass_of
    owner: MoleculeByChargeState
    domain_of:
    - OwlClass
    range: OwlClass
  id:
    name: id
    title: id
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    mappings:
    - schema:identifier
    rank: 1000

    range: string
    required: true

    title: name

docs.title: Class: molecule grouping class (MoleculeGroupingClass)
docs.text:
A grouping class that classifies molecules. Example: carbohydrate, monosaccharide, amino acid, polyacrylamide

URI: chemrof:MoleculeGroupingClass

description: 'A grouping class that classifies molecules. Example: carbohydrate, monosaccharide,
  amino acid, polyacrylamide'
title: molecule grouping class
comments:
- Unlike an actual molecule, a molecule grouping class will not have an inchi or properties
  such as mass
- Molecular grouping classes are typically defined by elemental composition and structure
  as well as chemical properties
examples:

      Note that subtype_of should only connect two grouping classes
    range: MoleculeGroupingClass
  classifies:
    name: classifies
    range: Molecule

docs.title: Direct
docs.text:
name: MoleculeGroupingClassDefinedByComponents
description: A grouping class defined as an exhaustive list of components
title: molecule grouping class defined by components
examples:
- value: nucleoside
  description: A nucleoside consists of a nucleobase and a five-carbon sugar (ribose
    or 2-deoxyribose)
- value: nucleotide
  description: a nucleotide is composed of a nucleobase, a five-carbon sugar, and
    one or more phosphate groups
from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
is_a: MoleculeGroupingClass
slots:
- has_part
slot_usage:
  has_part:
    name: has_part
    range: ChemicalEntityOrGrouping
defining_slots:
- has_part

    examples:
    - value: '[#1,#6:60][C@@:6]12[CX4:7][CX4H2,CX4H0:8]([CX4H3,CX4H2,#1:80])([CX4H3,CX4H2,#1:81])[CX3:9](=[CX3H2:10])[C@@:11]1([C:1](=[O:2])[CX4,c:4][CX4,c:3][CX4,c,O,NX3!r3:5]2)[C:99]#[N:97]>>[C:10]#[C:9][*:8]([*:80])([*:81])[C:7][C@@:6]1([*:60])[*:5][*:3][*:4][C:1](=[O:2])[C:11]1[C:99]#[N:97]'

  owl_subclass_of:
    name: owl_subclass_of
    description: 'Holds between C and P if C owl:subClassOf P. Note that in this model,
      most classes are metaclasses (see ''owl class''), where these metaclasses may
      represent *groupings* or specific countable elements or species. We provide
      two different sub-properties of subclass of for two cases: (1) subtype_of, which
      connects grouping classes (e.g. alkane is_a hydrocarbon; alpha-amino-acid is_a
      amino-acid), (2) classified_by, which connects a specific element to a grouping
      class (e.g. methane is_a hydrocarbon; iron is_a metal; serine is_a amino-acid)'
    title: owl subclass of
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof

    narrow_mappings:

    rank: 1000

    mixin: true

    owner: MoleculeGroupingClassDefinedByComponents
    domain_of:
    - OwlClass
    range: OwlClass
  name:

    description: name of chemical entity. E.g. nickel, carbon-16
    title: name

    close_mappings:

    is_a: information_property

    owner: MoleculeGroupingClassDefinedByComponents

  subtype_of:

    description: grouping classes can be arranged in hierarchies arbitrarily deep.

    title: subtype of
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof

    exact_mappings:

    narrow_mappings:

    rank: 1000
    is_a: chemical_to_chemical_relationship

    domain: OwlClass
    alias: subtype_of
    owner: MoleculeGroupingClassDefinedByComponents
    domain_of:
    - GroupingClass
    range: MoleculeGroupingClass
    required: false
    multivalued: true

    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    see_also:
    - https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/questions/151072/can-cis-trans-isomers-have-same-inchi
    aliases:
    - InChi
    exact_mappings:
    - OntoRXN:hasInChi
    rank: 1000
    is_a: chemical_formula
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: inchi_string
    owner: MonoatomicIon
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalEncoding
  inchi_chemical_sublayer:
    name: inchi_chemical_sublayer
    annotations:
      inchi.index:
        tag: inchi.index
        value: 2
    description: The part of an InChI string that represents the chemical formula,
      occurring after the version string. E.g. C6H12O6 for glucose
    title: inchi chemical sublayer
    comments:
    - in the case of hydrates, the dot separates the formula of the compound from
      the water molecules. For example, CuSO₄·5H₂O represents copper(II) sulfate pentahydrate,
      indicating that there are five water molecules associated with each copper(II)
      sulfate unit in the crystal.
    - 'Salt Formulations: Dots can also be used to denote the proportions in which
      different components are combined to form a salt. For instance, "CaCl₂·2AgNO₃"
      would suggest a complex formed from one unit of calcium chloride and two units
      of silver nitrate, though this particular example is more illustrative than
      practical.'
    - 'Coordination Complexes: In coordination chemistry, dots can separate the metal
      complex from its counterions or ligands that are not directly bonded to the
      metal center. For example, "[Co(NH₃)₆]Cl₃" indicates a complex of cobalt with
      six ammonia ligands, and the three chloride ions are counterions. If written
      as "[Co(NH₃)₆]·3Cl", it would similarly denote the presence of three chloride
      ions associated with the complex, though this notation is less common'
    - 'Molecular Assemblies: For certain supramolecular structures or assemblies,
      dots might be used to indicate a non-covalent association of components. This
      usage is less common and more context-dependent'
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: inchi_sublayer_in_main_layer
    alias: inchi_chemical_sublayer
    owner: MonoatomicIon
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    - StandardInchiObject
    - EntityWithAtomsEnumerated
    range: string
    required: false
    recommended: true
    pattern: ^[A-Z0-9\.]+$
  smiles_string:
    name: smiles_string
    description: A string encoding of a molecular graph, no chiral or isotopic information.
      There are usually a large number of valid SMILES which represent a given structure.
      For example, CCO, OCC and C(O)C all specify the structure of ethanol.
    title: smiles string
    comments:
    - a problematic set of structures to describe using SMILES notation is those which
      cannot be easily described using molecular graphs (see “Limitations of molecular
      graph representations” section), such as organometallic compounds and ionic
      salts.
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: chemical_formula
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: smiles_string
    owner: MonoatomicIon
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalEncoding
  empirical_formula:
    name: empirical_formula
    description: A chemical formula where numbers denote relative proportion of atoms.
      E.g. CH2O for glucose
    title: empirical formula
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: chemical_formula
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: empirical_formula
    owner: MonoatomicIon
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalEncoding
  has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3:
    name: has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3
    description: Links different variants of the same chemical in different protonation
      states, where the target of this link is the (predicited) to be most common
      protonation state for this chemical at a pH of 7.3. This link may point to it's
      source. Connects an acid to the form that is stable at physiological pH (7.3).
      E.g. citric acid has physiological base citrate(3-)
    title: has physiologically stable form
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    see_also:
    - https://ftp.expasy.org/databases/rhea/tsv/chebi_pH7_3_mapping.tsv
    aliases:
    - protonation neutral form of
    - has Ph 7.3 mapping
    rank: 1000
    is_a: acid_form_of
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3
    owner: MonoatomicIon
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    inverse: major_microspecies_at_pH7_3_of
    range: ChemicalEntity
    multivalued: true
  molecular_mass:
    name: molecular_mass
    description: The sum of the relative atomic masses of the constituent atoms of
      a molecule.
    title: molecular mass
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof

  owl_subclass_of:

    description: 'Holds between C and P if C owl:subClassOf P. Note that in this model,
      most classes are metaclasses (see ''owl class''), where these metaclasses may

      two different sub-properties of subclass of for two cases: (1) subtype_of, which
      connects grouping classes (e.g. alkane is_a hydrocarbon; alpha-amino-acid is_a
      amino-acid), (2) classified_by, which connects a specific element to a grouping
      class (e.g. methane is_a hydrocarbon; iron is_a metal; serine is_a amino-acid)'
    title: owl subclass of
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    aliases:
    - is a

    - rdfs:subClassOf

attributes:
  inchi_atom_connections_sublayer:
    name: inchi_atom_connections_sublayer
    description: The atoms in the chemical formula (except for hydrogens) are numbered
      in sequence; this sublayer describes which atoms are connected by bonds to which
      other ones.
    title: inchi atom connections sublayer
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: inchi_sublayer_in_main_layer
    alias: inchi_atom_connections_sublayer
    owner: Monomer
    domain_of:

    - StandardInchiObject
    - EntityWithConnectivitySpecificied
    range: string
    required: false
    recommended: true
    pattern: ^c.*
  IUPAC_name:
    name: IUPAC_name

    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    exact_mappings:
    - MI:2007
    rank: 1000

    alias: IUPAC_name

    - ChemicalEntity
    range: string
  is_radical:
