    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: is_radical
    owner: Monomer
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: boolean
  has_chemical_role:
    name: has_chemical_role
    title: has chemical role
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    alias: has_chemical_role
    owner: Monomer
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalRole
  inchi_string:
    name: inchi_string
    title: InChi
    todos:
    - declare this as a key once compound_key is introduced to linkml
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    see_also:
    - https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/questions/151072/can-cis-trans-isomers-have-same-inchi
    aliases:
    - InChi
    exact_mappings:
    - OntoRXN:hasInChi
    rank: 1000
    is_a: chemical_formula
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: inchi_string
    owner: Monomer
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalEncoding
  inchi_chemical_sublayer:
    name: inchi_chemical_sublayer
    annotations:
      inchi.index:
        tag: inchi.index
        value: 2
    description: The part of an InChI string that represents the chemical formula,
      occurring after the version string. E.g. C6H12O6 for glucose
    title: inchi chemical sublayer
    comments:
    - in the case of hydrates, the dot separates the formula of the compound from
      the water molecules. For example, CuSO₄·5H₂O represents copper(II) sulfate pentahydrate,
      indicating that there are five water molecules associated with each copper(II)
      sulfate unit in the crystal.
    - 'Salt Formulations: Dots can also be used to denote the proportions in which
      different components are combined to form a salt. For instance, "CaCl₂·2AgNO₃"
      would suggest a complex formed from one unit of calcium chloride and two units
      of silver nitrate, though this particular example is more illustrative than
      practical.'
    - 'Coordination Complexes: In coordination chemistry, dots can separate the metal
      complex from its counterions or ligands that are not directly bonded to the
      metal center. For example, "[Co(NH₃)₆]Cl₃" indicates a complex of cobalt with
      six ammonia ligands, and the three chloride ions are counterions. If written
      as "[Co(NH₃)₆]·3Cl", it would similarly denote the presence of three chloride
      ions associated with the complex, though this notation is less common'
    - 'Molecular Assemblies: For certain supramolecular structures or assemblies,
      dots might be used to indicate a non-covalent association of components. This
      usage is less common and more context-dependent'
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: inchi_sublayer_in_main_layer
    alias: inchi_chemical_sublayer
    owner: Monomer
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    - StandardInchiObject
    - EntityWithAtomsEnumerated
    range: string
    required: false
    recommended: true
    pattern: ^[A-Z0-9\.]+$
  smiles_string:
    name: smiles_string
    description: A string encoding of a molecular graph, no chiral or isotopic information.
      There are usually a large number of valid SMILES which represent a given structure.
      For example, CCO, OCC and C(O)C all specify the structure of ethanol.
    title: smiles string
    comments:
    - a problematic set of structures to describe using SMILES notation is those which
      cannot be easily described using molecular graphs (see “Limitations of molecular
      graph representations” section), such as organometallic compounds and ionic
      salts.
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: chemical_formula
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: smiles_string
    owner: Monomer
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalEncoding
  empirical_formula:
    name: empirical_formula
    description: A chemical formula where numbers denote relative proportion of atoms.
      E.g. CH2O for glucose
    title: empirical formula
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: chemical_formula
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: empirical_formula
    owner: Monomer
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalEncoding
  has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3:
    name: has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3
    description: Links different variants of the same chemical in different protonation
      states, where the target of this link is the (predicited) to be most common
      protonation state for this chemical at a pH of 7.3. This link may point to it's
      source. Connects an acid to the form that is stable at physiological pH (7.3).
      E.g. citric acid has physiological base citrate(3-)
    title: has physiologically stable form
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    see_also:
    - https://ftp.expasy.org/databases/rhea/tsv/chebi_pH7_3_mapping.tsv
    aliases:
    - protonation neutral form of
    - has Ph 7.3 mapping
    rank: 1000
    is_a: acid_form_of
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3
    owner: Monomer
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    inverse: major_microspecies_at_pH7_3_of
    range: ChemicalEntity
    multivalued: true
  molecular_mass:
    name: molecular_mass
    description: The sum of the relative atomic masses of the constituent atoms of
      a molecule.
    title: molecular mass
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    exact_mappings:
    - NCIT:C28272
    - FIX:0000270
    - chebi.property:mass
    rank: 1000
    is_a: molecular_property
    alias: molecular_mass
    owner: Monomer
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: float
    unit:
      ucum_code: u
  owl_subclass_of:
    name: owl_subclass_of
    description: 'Holds between C and P if C owl:subClassOf P. Note that in this model,
      most classes are metaclasses (see ''owl class''), where these metaclasses may
      represent *groupings* or specific countable elements or species. We provide
      two different sub-properties of subclass of for two cases: (1) subtype_of, which
      connects grouping classes (e.g. alkane is_a hydrocarbon; alpha-amino-acid is_a
      amino-acid), (2) classified_by, which connects a specific element to a grouping
      class (e.g. methane is_a hydrocarbon; iron is_a metal; serine is_a amino-acid)'
    title: owl subclass of
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    aliases:
    - is a
    exact_mappings:

    narrow_mappings:

    owner: Monomer
    domain_of:
    - OwlClass
    range: OwlClass
  id:

    title: id
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof

    rank: 1000

  has_chemical_role:

    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    alias: has_chemical_role
    owner: MonomolecularPolymer

    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalRole
  inchi_string:
    name: inchi_string
    title: InChi
    todos:
    - declare this as a key once compound_key is introduced to linkml
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    see_also:
    - https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/questions/151072/can-cis-trans-isomers-have-same-inchi
    aliases:
    - InChi
    exact_mappings:
    - OntoRXN:hasInChi
    rank: 1000
    is_a: chemical_formula
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: inchi_string
    owner: MonomolecularPolymer
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalEncoding
  inchi_chemical_sublayer:
    name: inchi_chemical_sublayer
    annotations:
      inchi.index:
        tag: inchi.index
        value: 2
    description: The part of an InChI string that represents the chemical formula,
      occurring after the version string. E.g. C6H12O6 for glucose
    title: inchi chemical sublayer
    comments:
    - in the case of hydrates, the dot separates the formula of the compound from
      the water molecules. For example, CuSO₄·5H₂O represents copper(II) sulfate pentahydrate,
      indicating that there are five water molecules associated with each copper(II)
      sulfate unit in the crystal.
    - 'Salt Formulations: Dots can also be used to denote the proportions in which
      different components are combined to form a salt. For instance, "CaCl₂·2AgNO₃"
      would suggest a complex formed from one unit of calcium chloride and two units
      of silver nitrate, though this particular example is more illustrative than
      practical.'
    - 'Coordination Complexes: In coordination chemistry, dots can separate the metal
      complex from its counterions or ligands that are not directly bonded to the
      metal center. For example, "[Co(NH₃)₆]Cl₃" indicates a complex of cobalt with
      six ammonia ligands, and the three chloride ions are counterions. If written
      as "[Co(NH₃)₆]·3Cl", it would similarly denote the presence of three chloride
      ions associated with the complex, though this notation is less common'
    - 'Molecular Assemblies: For certain supramolecular structures or assemblies,
      dots might be used to indicate a non-covalent association of components. This
      usage is less common and more context-dependent'
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: inchi_sublayer_in_main_layer
    alias: inchi_chemical_sublayer
    owner: MonomolecularPolymer
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    - StandardInchiObject
    - EntityWithAtomsEnumerated
    range: string
    required: false
    recommended: true
    pattern: ^[A-Z0-9\.]+$
  smiles_string:
    name: smiles_string
    description: A string encoding of a molecular graph, no chiral or isotopic information.
      There are usually a large number of valid SMILES which represent a given structure.
      For example, CCO, OCC and C(O)C all specify the structure of ethanol.
    title: smiles string
    comments:
    - a problematic set of structures to describe using SMILES notation is those which
      cannot be easily described using molecular graphs (see “Limitations of molecular
      graph representations” section), such as organometallic compounds and ionic
      salts.
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: chemical_formula
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: smiles_string
    owner: MonomolecularPolymer
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalEncoding
  empirical_formula:
    name: empirical_formula
    description: A chemical formula where numbers denote relative proportion of atoms.
      E.g. CH2O for glucose
    title: empirical formula
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: chemical_formula
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: empirical_formula
    owner: MonomolecularPolymer
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalEncoding
  has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3:
    name: has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3
    description: Links different variants of the same chemical in different protonation
      states, where the target of this link is the (predicited) to be most common
      protonation state for this chemical at a pH of 7.3. This link may point to it's
      source. Connects an acid to the form that is stable at physiological pH (7.3).
      E.g. citric acid has physiological base citrate(3-)
    title: has physiologically stable form
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    see_also:
    - https://ftp.expasy.org/databases/rhea/tsv/chebi_pH7_3_mapping.tsv
    aliases:
    - protonation neutral form of
    - has Ph 7.3 mapping
    rank: 1000
    is_a: acid_form_of
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3
    owner: MonomolecularPolymer
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    inverse: major_microspecies_at_pH7_3_of
    range: ChemicalEntity
    multivalued: true
  molecular_mass:
    name: molecular_mass
    description: The sum of the relative atomic masses of the constituent atoms of
      a molecule.
    title: molecular mass
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    exact_mappings:
    - NCIT:C28272
    - FIX:0000270
    - chebi.property:mass
    rank: 1000
    is_a: molecular_property
    alias: molecular_mass
    owner: MonomolecularPolymer
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: float
    unit:
      ucum_code: u
  owl_subclass_of:
    name: owl_subclass_of
    description: 'Holds between C and P if C owl:subClassOf P. Note that in this model,
      most classes are metaclasses (see ''owl class''), where these metaclasses may
      represent *groupings* or specific countable elements or species. We provide
      two different sub-properties of subclass of for two cases: (1) subtype_of, which
      connects grouping classes (e.g. alkane is_a hydrocarbon; alpha-amino-acid is_a
      amino-acid), (2) classified_by, which connects a specific element to a grouping
      class (e.g. methane is_a hydrocarbon; iron is_a metal; serine is_a amino-acid)'
    title: owl subclass of
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    aliases:
    - is a
    exact_mappings:
    - rdfs:subClassOf
    narrow_mappings:
    - bo:family
    rank: 1000
    is_a: classification_relationship
    mixin: true
    domain: OwlClass
    alias: owl_subclass_of
    owner: MonomolecularPolymer
    domain_of:
    - OwlClass
    range: OwlClass
  id:
    name: id
    title: id
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    mappings:
    - schema:identifier
    rank: 1000
    is_a: information_property
    identifier: true
    alias: id
    owner: MonomolecularPolymer
    domain_of:
    - DomainEntity
    - GroupingClass
    - ChemicalGroupingClass
    range: string
    required: true
  name:
    name: name
    description: name of chemical entity. E.g. nickel, carbon-16
    title: name

    close_mappings:

    alias: name

    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000

docs.title: Class: nanomaterial (Nanomaterial)
docs.text:
A material of which a single unit is sized (in at least one dimension) between 1 and 100 nm

URI: chemrof:Nanomaterial

 classDiagram
    class Nanomaterial
    click Nanomaterial href "../Nanomaterial"
      Material <|-- Nanomaterial
        click Material href "../Material"

      Nanomaterial : has_repeat_unit





        Nanomaterial --> "0..1" ChemicalEntity : has_repeat_unit
        click ChemicalEntity href "../ChemicalEntity"



      Nanomaterial : id

      Nanomaterial : name

      Nanomaterial : type

  inchi_string:
    name: inchi_string
    title: InChi
    todos:
    - declare this as a key once compound_key is introduced to linkml
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    see_also:
    - https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/questions/151072/can-cis-trans-isomers-have-same-inchi
    aliases:
    - InChi
    exact_mappings:
    - OntoRXN:hasInChi
    rank: 1000
    is_a: chemical_formula
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: inchi_string
    owner: NaturalProduct
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalEncoding
  inchi_chemical_sublayer:
    name: inchi_chemical_sublayer
    annotations:
      inchi.index:
        tag: inchi.index
        value: 2
    description: The part of an InChI string that represents the chemical formula,
      occurring after the version string. E.g. C6H12O6 for glucose
    title: inchi chemical sublayer
    comments:
    - in the case of hydrates, the dot separates the formula of the compound from
      the water molecules. For example, CuSO₄·5H₂O represents copper(II) sulfate pentahydrate,
      indicating that there are five water molecules associated with each copper(II)
      sulfate unit in the crystal.
    - 'Salt Formulations: Dots can also be used to denote the proportions in which
      different components are combined to form a salt. For instance, "CaCl₂·2AgNO₃"
      would suggest a complex formed from one unit of calcium chloride and two units
      of silver nitrate, though this particular example is more illustrative than
      practical.'
    - 'Coordination Complexes: In coordination chemistry, dots can separate the metal
      complex from its counterions or ligands that are not directly bonded to the
      metal center. For example, "[Co(NH₃)₆]Cl₃" indicates a complex of cobalt with
      six ammonia ligands, and the three chloride ions are counterions. If written
      as "[Co(NH₃)₆]·3Cl", it would similarly denote the presence of three chloride
      ions associated with the complex, though this notation is less common'
    - 'Molecular Assemblies: For certain supramolecular structures or assemblies,
      dots might be used to indicate a non-covalent association of components. This
      usage is less common and more context-dependent'
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: inchi_sublayer_in_main_layer
    alias: inchi_chemical_sublayer
    owner: NaturalProduct
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    - StandardInchiObject
    - EntityWithAtomsEnumerated
    range: string
    required: false
    recommended: true
    pattern: ^[A-Z0-9\.]+$
  smiles_string:
    name: smiles_string
    description: A string encoding of a molecular graph, no chiral or isotopic information.
      There are usually a large number of valid SMILES which represent a given structure.
      For example, CCO, OCC and C(O)C all specify the structure of ethanol.
    title: smiles string
    comments:
    - a problematic set of structures to describe using SMILES notation is those which
      cannot be easily described using molecular graphs (see “Limitations of molecular
      graph representations” section), such as organometallic compounds and ionic
      salts.
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: chemical_formula
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: smiles_string
    owner: NaturalProduct
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalEncoding
  empirical_formula:
    name: empirical_formula
    description: A chemical formula where numbers denote relative proportion of atoms.
      E.g. CH2O for glucose
    title: empirical formula
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: chemical_formula
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: empirical_formula
    owner: NaturalProduct
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalEncoding
  has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3:
    name: has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3
    description: Links different variants of the same chemical in different protonation
      states, where the target of this link is the (predicited) to be most common
      protonation state for this chemical at a pH of 7.3. This link may point to it's
      source. Connects an acid to the form that is stable at physiological pH (7.3).
      E.g. citric acid has physiological base citrate(3-)
    title: has physiologically stable form
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    see_also:
    - https://ftp.expasy.org/databases/rhea/tsv/chebi_pH7_3_mapping.tsv
    aliases:
    - protonation neutral form of
    - has Ph 7.3 mapping
    rank: 1000
    is_a: acid_form_of
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3
    owner: NaturalProduct
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    inverse: major_microspecies_at_pH7_3_of
    range: ChemicalEntity
    multivalued: true
  molecular_mass:
    name: molecular_mass
    description: The sum of the relative atomic masses of the constituent atoms of
      a molecule.
    title: molecular mass
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    exact_mappings:
    - NCIT:C28272
    - FIX:0000270
    - chebi.property:mass
    rank: 1000
    is_a: molecular_property
    alias: molecular_mass
    owner: NaturalProduct
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: float
    unit:
      ucum_code: u
  owl_subclass_of:
    name: owl_subclass_of
    description: 'Holds between C and P if C owl:subClassOf P. Note that in this model,
      most classes are metaclasses (see ''owl class''), where these metaclasses may
      represent *groupings* or specific countable elements or species. We provide
      two different sub-properties of subclass of for two cases: (1) subtype_of, which
      connects grouping classes (e.g. alkane is_a hydrocarbon; alpha-amino-acid is_a
      amino-acid), (2) classified_by, which connects a specific element to a grouping
      class (e.g. methane is_a hydrocarbon; iron is_a metal; serine is_a amino-acid)'
    title: owl subclass of

docs.title: Class: neutral molecule (NeutralMolecule)
docs.text:

attributes:
  bronsted_acid_base_role:
    name: bronsted_acid_base_role

    owner: NeutralMolecule

    multivalued: true
  has_atoms:

    description: 'Relation between a molecule and the atoms it contains. Note that

    title: has atoms
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000

    title: is organic

    range: boolean
  inchi_atom_connections_sublayer:
    name: inchi_atom_connections_sublayer
    description: The atoms in the chemical formula (except for hydrogens) are numbered
      in sequence; this sublayer describes which atoms are connected by bonds to which

    title: inchi atom connections sublayer
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof

    alias: inchi_atom_connections_sublayer
    owner: NeutralMolecule
    domain_of:
    - PolyatomicEntity
    - StandardInchiObject
    - EntityWithConnectivitySpecificied
    range: string
    required: false
    recommended: true
    pattern: ^c.*
  IUPAC_name:

    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    exact_mappings:
    - MI:2007
    rank: 1000

    slot_uri: CHEMINF:000107
    alias: IUPAC_name
    owner: NeutralMolecule
    domain_of:

    range: string
  is_radical:

    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: is_radical
    owner: NeutralMolecule
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: boolean
  has_chemical_role:
    name: has_chemical_role
    title: has chemical role
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    alias: has_chemical_role
    owner: NeutralMolecule
    domain_of:

  inchi_string:
    name: inchi_string
    title: InChi
    todos:
    - declare this as a key once compound_key is introduced to linkml
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    see_also:
    - https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/questions/151072/can-cis-trans-isomers-have-same-inchi
    aliases:
    - InChi
    exact_mappings:
    - OntoRXN:hasInChi
    rank: 1000
    is_a: chemical_formula
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: inchi_string
    owner: NeutralMolecule
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalEncoding
  inchi_chemical_sublayer:
    name: inchi_chemical_sublayer
    annotations:
      inchi.index:
        tag: inchi.index
        value: 2
    description: The part of an InChI string that represents the chemical formula,
      occurring after the version string. E.g. C6H12O6 for glucose
    title: inchi chemical sublayer
    comments:
    - in the case of hydrates, the dot separates the formula of the compound from
      the water molecules. For example, CuSO₄·5H₂O represents copper(II) sulfate pentahydrate,
      indicating that there are five water molecules associated with each copper(II)
      sulfate unit in the crystal.
    - 'Salt Formulations: Dots can also be used to denote the proportions in which
      different components are combined to form a salt. For instance, "CaCl₂·2AgNO₃"
      would suggest a complex formed from one unit of calcium chloride and two units
      of silver nitrate, though this particular example is more illustrative than
      practical.'
    - 'Coordination Complexes: In coordination chemistry, dots can separate the metal
      complex from its counterions or ligands that are not directly bonded to the
      metal center. For example, "[Co(NH₃)₆]Cl₃" indicates a complex of cobalt with
      six ammonia ligands, and the three chloride ions are counterions. If written
      as "[Co(NH₃)₆]·3Cl", it would similarly denote the presence of three chloride
      ions associated with the complex, though this notation is less common'
    - 'Molecular Assemblies: For certain supramolecular structures or assemblies,
      dots might be used to indicate a non-covalent association of components. This
      usage is less common and more context-dependent'
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: inchi_sublayer_in_main_layer
    alias: inchi_chemical_sublayer
    owner: NeutralMolecule
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    - StandardInchiObject
    - EntityWithAtomsEnumerated
    range: string
    required: false
    recommended: true
    pattern: ^[A-Z0-9\.]+$
  smiles_string:
    name: smiles_string
    description: A string encoding of a molecular graph, no chiral or isotopic information.
      There are usually a large number of valid SMILES which represent a given structure.
      For example, CCO, OCC and C(O)C all specify the structure of ethanol.
    title: smiles string
    comments:
    - a problematic set of structures to describe using SMILES notation is those which
      cannot be easily described using molecular graphs (see “Limitations of molecular
      graph representations” section), such as organometallic compounds and ionic
      salts.
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: chemical_formula
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: smiles_string
    owner: NeutralMolecule
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalEncoding
  empirical_formula:
    name: empirical_formula
    description: A chemical formula where numbers denote relative proportion of atoms.
      E.g. CH2O for glucose
    title: empirical formula
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: chemical_formula
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: empirical_formula
    owner: NeutralMolecule
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalEncoding
  has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3:
    name: has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3
    description: Links different variants of the same chemical in different protonation
      states, where the target of this link is the (predicited) to be most common
      protonation state for this chemical at a pH of 7.3. This link may point to it's
      source. Connects an acid to the form that is stable at physiological pH (7.3).
      E.g. citric acid has physiological base citrate(3-)
    title: has physiologically stable form
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    see_also:
    - https://ftp.expasy.org/databases/rhea/tsv/chebi_pH7_3_mapping.tsv
    aliases:
    - protonation neutral form of
    - has Ph 7.3 mapping
    rank: 1000
    is_a: acid_form_of
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3
    owner: NeutralMolecule
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    inverse: major_microspecies_at_pH7_3_of
    range: ChemicalEntity
    multivalued: true
  molecular_mass:
    name: molecular_mass
    description: The sum of the relative atomic masses of the constituent atoms of
      a molecule.
    title: molecular mass
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    exact_mappings:
    - NCIT:C28272
    - FIX:0000270
    - chebi.property:mass
    rank: 1000
    is_a: molecular_property
    alias: molecular_mass
    owner: NeutralMolecule
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: float
    unit:
      ucum_code: u
  owl_subclass_of:
    name: owl_subclass_of
    description: 'Holds between C and P if C owl:subClassOf P. Note that in this model,
      most classes are metaclasses (see ''owl class''), where these metaclasses may
      represent *groupings* or specific countable elements or species. We provide
      two different sub-properties of subclass of for two cases: (1) subtype_of, which
      connects grouping classes (e.g. alkane is_a hydrocarbon; alpha-amino-acid is_a
      amino-acid), (2) classified_by, which connects a specific element to a grouping
      class (e.g. methane is_a hydrocarbon; iron is_a metal; serine is_a amino-acid)'
    title: owl subclass of
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    aliases:
    - is a
    exact_mappings:
    - rdfs:subClassOf
    narrow_mappings:
    - bo:family
    rank: 1000
    is_a: classification_relationship
    mixin: true
    domain: OwlClass
    alias: owl_subclass_of
    owner: NeutralMolecule
    domain_of:
    - OwlClass
    range: OwlClass
  id:
    name: id
    title: id
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    mappings:
    - schema:identifier
    rank: 1000
    is_a: information_property
    identifier: true
    alias: id
    owner: NeutralMolecule
    domain_of:
    - DomainEntity
    - GroupingClass
    - ChemicalGroupingClass
    range: string
    required: true
  name:
    name: name
    description: name of chemical entity. E.g. nickel, carbon-16
    title: name
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    close_mappings:

    rank: 1000

    alias: name
    owner: NeutralMolecule
    domain_of:
    - DomainEntity
    - GroupingClass
    - Atom
    - AtomOccurrence
    range: string
  type:
    name: type
    title: type
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    designates_type: true
    alias: type
    owner: NeutralMolecule
    domain_of:
    - DomainEntity
    range: uriorcurie
  elemental_charge:
    name: elemental_charge
    description: number of protons minus number of electrons
    title: elemental charge
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    mappings:

    rank: 1000

      different components are combined to form a salt. For instance, "CaCl₂·2AgNO₃"
      would suggest a complex formed from one unit of calcium chloride and two units
      of silver nitrate, though this particular example is more illustrative than
      practical.'
    - 'Coordination Complexes: In coordination chemistry, dots can separate the metal
      complex from its counterions or ligands that are not directly bonded to the
      metal center. For example, "[Co(NH₃)₆]Cl₃" indicates a complex of cobalt with
      six ammonia ligands, and the three chloride ions are counterions. If written
      as "[Co(NH₃)₆]·3Cl", it would similarly denote the presence of three chloride
      ions associated with the complex, though this notation is less common'
    - 'Molecular Assemblies: For certain supramolecular structures or assemblies,
      dots might be used to indicate a non-covalent association of components. This
      usage is less common and more context-dependent'
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof

      There are usually a large number of valid SMILES which represent a given structure.
      For example, CCO, OCC and C(O)C all specify the structure of ethanol.

    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: string

    title: is radical
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: is_radical
    owner: Nuclide
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: boolean
  has_chemical_role:
    name: has_chemical_role
    title: has chemical role
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    alias: has_chemical_role
    owner: Nuclide

  inchi_string:
    name: inchi_string
    title: InChi
    todos:
    - declare this as a key once compound_key is introduced to linkml
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    see_also:
    - https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/questions/151072/can-cis-trans-isomers-have-same-inchi
    aliases:
    - InChi
    exact_mappings:
    - OntoRXN:hasInChi
    rank: 1000
    is_a: chemical_formula
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: inchi_string
    owner: Nuclide
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalEncoding
  inchi_chemical_sublayer:
    name: inchi_chemical_sublayer
    annotations:
      inchi.index:
        tag: inchi.index
        value: 2
    description: The part of an InChI string that represents the chemical formula,
      occurring after the version string. E.g. C6H12O6 for glucose
    title: inchi chemical sublayer
    comments:
    - in the case of hydrates, the dot separates the formula of the compound from
      the water molecules. For example, CuSO₄·5H₂O represents copper(II) sulfate pentahydrate,
      indicating that there are five water molecules associated with each copper(II)
      sulfate unit in the crystal.
    - 'Salt Formulations: Dots can also be used to denote the proportions in which
      different components are combined to form a salt. For instance, "CaCl₂·2AgNO₃"
      would suggest a complex formed from one unit of calcium chloride and two units
      of silver nitrate, though this particular example is more illustrative than
      practical.'
    - 'Coordination Complexes: In coordination chemistry, dots can separate the metal
      complex from its counterions or ligands that are not directly bonded to the
      metal center. For example, "[Co(NH₃)₆]Cl₃" indicates a complex of cobalt with
      six ammonia ligands, and the three chloride ions are counterions. If written
      as "[Co(NH₃)₆]·3Cl", it would similarly denote the presence of three chloride
      ions associated with the complex, though this notation is less common'
    - 'Molecular Assemblies: For certain supramolecular structures or assemblies,
      dots might be used to indicate a non-covalent association of components. This
      usage is less common and more context-dependent'
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: inchi_sublayer_in_main_layer
    alias: inchi_chemical_sublayer
    owner: Nuclide
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    - StandardInchiObject
    - EntityWithAtomsEnumerated
    range: string
    required: false
    recommended: true
    pattern: ^[A-Z0-9\.]+$
  smiles_string:
    name: smiles_string
    description: A string encoding of a molecular graph, no chiral or isotopic information.
      There are usually a large number of valid SMILES which represent a given structure.
      For example, CCO, OCC and C(O)C all specify the structure of ethanol.
    title: smiles string
    comments:
    - a problematic set of structures to describe using SMILES notation is those which
      cannot be easily described using molecular graphs (see “Limitations of molecular
      graph representations” section), such as organometallic compounds and ionic
      salts.
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: chemical_formula
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: smiles_string
    owner: Nuclide
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalEncoding
  empirical_formula:
    name: empirical_formula
    description: A chemical formula where numbers denote relative proportion of atoms.
      E.g. CH2O for glucose
    title: empirical formula
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: chemical_formula
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: empirical_formula
    owner: Nuclide
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalEncoding
  has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3:
    name: has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3
    description: Links different variants of the same chemical in different protonation
      states, where the target of this link is the (predicited) to be most common
      protonation state for this chemical at a pH of 7.3. This link may point to it's
      source. Connects an acid to the form that is stable at physiological pH (7.3).
      E.g. citric acid has physiological base citrate(3-)
    title: has physiologically stable form
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    see_also:
    - https://ftp.expasy.org/databases/rhea/tsv/chebi_pH7_3_mapping.tsv
    aliases:
    - protonation neutral form of
    - has Ph 7.3 mapping
    rank: 1000
    is_a: acid_form_of
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3
    owner: Nuclide
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    inverse: major_microspecies_at_pH7_3_of
    range: ChemicalEntity
    multivalued: true
  molecular_mass:
    name: molecular_mass
    description: The sum of the relative atomic masses of the constituent atoms of
      a molecule.
    title: molecular mass
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    exact_mappings:
    - NCIT:C28272
    - FIX:0000270
    - chebi.property:mass
    rank: 1000
    is_a: molecular_property
    alias: molecular_mass
    owner: Nuclide
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: float
    unit:
      ucum_code: u
  owl_subclass_of:
    name: owl_subclass_of
    description: 'Holds between C and P if C owl:subClassOf P. Note that in this model,
      most classes are metaclasses (see ''owl class''), where these metaclasses may
      represent *groupings* or specific countable elements or species. We provide
      two different sub-properties of subclass of for two cases: (1) subtype_of, which
      connects grouping classes (e.g. alkane is_a hydrocarbon; alpha-amino-acid is_a
      amino-acid), (2) classified_by, which connects a specific element to a grouping
      class (e.g. methane is_a hydrocarbon; iron is_a metal; serine is_a amino-acid)'
    title: owl subclass of
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    aliases:
    - is a
    exact_mappings:
    - rdfs:subClassOf
    narrow_mappings:

    range: OwlClass

docs.title: Class: partially specified atom (PartiallySpecifiedAtom)
docs.text:
An atom type that only has a subset of properties (has atomic number, charge, and neutron number) stated

  • NOTE: this is an abstract class and should not be instantiated directly

URI: chemrof:PartiallySpecifiedAtom

 classDiagram
    class PartiallySpecifiedAtom
    click PartiallySpecifiedAtom href "../PartiallySpecifiedAtom"
      Atom <|-- PartiallySpecifiedAtom
        click Atom href "../Atom"


      PartiallySpecifiedAtom <|-- ChemicalElement
        click ChemicalElement href "../ChemicalElement"
      PartiallySpecifiedAtom <|-- Nuclide
        click Nuclide href "../Nuclide"
      PartiallySpecifiedAtom <|-- AtomIonicForm
        click AtomIonicForm href "../AtomIonicForm"


      PartiallySpecifiedAtom : atomic_number

      PartiallySpecifiedAtom : empirical_formula

        click ChemicalRole href "../ChemicalRole"

        PartiallySpecifiedAtom --> "*" ChemicalEntity : has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3
        click ChemicalEntity href "../ChemicalEntity"

name: PartiallySpecifiedAtom

  charge, and neutron number) stated
title: partially specified atom
from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
is_a: Atom
abstract: true

docs.title: Induced
docs.text:
name: PartiallySpecifiedAtom
description: An atom type that only has a subset of properties (has atomic number,
  charge, and neutron number) stated
title: partially specified atom
from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
is_a: Atom
abstract: true
attributes:
  atomic_number:
    name: atomic_number
    description: number of protons in an atom
    title: atomic number
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    aliases:
    - proton number
    - Z
    mappings:
    - CHEMINF:000079
    exact_mappings:
    - wd:P1086
    rank: 1000
    is_a: subatomic_particle_count
    domain: Atom
    slot_uri: bo:atomicNumber
    alias: atomic_number
    owner: PartiallySpecifiedAtom
    domain_of:
    - Atom
    range: Count
  symbol:
    name: symbol
    description: short symbol for chemical entity, e.g. K, C-16
    title: symbol
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: information_property
    slot_uri: bo:symbol
    alias: symbol
    owner: PartiallySpecifiedAtom
    domain_of:
    - Atom
    range: string
  name:
    name: name
    description: name of chemical entity. E.g. nickel, carbon-16
    title: name
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    close_mappings:
    - bo:symbol
    rank: 1000
    is_a: information_property
    slot_uri: rdfs:label
    alias: name
    owner: PartiallySpecifiedAtom
    domain_of:
    - DomainEntity
    - GroupingClass
    - Atom
    - AtomOccurrence
    range: string
  has_nuclear_parts:
    name: has_nuclear_parts
    title: has nuclear parts
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: property_of_atom
    domain: Atom
    alias: has_nuclear_parts
    owner: PartiallySpecifiedAtom
    domain_of:
    - Atom
    range: SubatomicParticleOccurrence
  IUPAC_name:
    name: IUPAC_name
    title: IUPAC name
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    exact_mappings:
    - MI:2007
    rank: 1000
    is_a: information_property
    slot_uri: CHEMINF:000107
    alias: IUPAC_name
    owner: PartiallySpecifiedAtom
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: string
  is_radical:
    name: is_radical
    title: is radical
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: is_radical
    owner: PartiallySpecifiedAtom
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: boolean
  has_chemical_role:
    name: has_chemical_role
    title: has chemical role
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    alias: has_chemical_role
    owner: PartiallySpecifiedAtom
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalRole
  inchi_string:
    name: inchi_string
    title: InChi
    todos:
    - declare this as a key once compound_key is introduced to linkml
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    see_also:
    - https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/questions/151072/can-cis-trans-isomers-have-same-inchi
    aliases:
    - InChi
    exact_mappings:
    - OntoRXN:hasInChi
    rank: 1000
    is_a: chemical_formula
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: inchi_string
    owner: PartiallySpecifiedAtom
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalEncoding
  inchi_chemical_sublayer:
    name: inchi_chemical_sublayer
    annotations:
      inchi.index:
        tag: inchi.index
        value: 2
    description: The part of an InChI string that represents the chemical formula,
      occurring after the version string. E.g. C6H12O6 for glucose
    title: inchi chemical sublayer
    comments:
    - in the case of hydrates, the dot separates the formula of the compound from
      the water molecules. For example, CuSO₄·5H₂O represents copper(II) sulfate pentahydrate,
      indicating that there are five water molecules associated with each copper(II)
      sulfate unit in the crystal.
    - 'Salt Formulations: Dots can also be used to denote the proportions in which
      different components are combined to form a salt. For instance, "CaCl₂·2AgNO₃"
      would suggest a complex formed from one unit of calcium chloride and two units
      of silver nitrate, though this particular example is more illustrative than
      practical.'
    - 'Coordination Complexes: In coordination chemistry, dots can separate the metal
      complex from its counterions or ligands that are not directly bonded to the
      metal center. For example, "[Co(NH₃)₆]Cl₃" indicates a complex of cobalt with
      six ammonia ligands, and the three chloride ions are counterions. If written
      as "[Co(NH₃)₆]·3Cl", it would similarly denote the presence of three chloride
      ions associated with the complex, though this notation is less common'
    - 'Molecular Assemblies: For certain supramolecular structures or assemblies,
      dots might be used to indicate a non-covalent association of components. This
      usage is less common and more context-dependent'
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: inchi_sublayer_in_main_layer
    alias: inchi_chemical_sublayer
    owner: PartiallySpecifiedAtom
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    - StandardInchiObject
    - EntityWithAtomsEnumerated
    range: string
    required: false
    recommended: true
    pattern: ^[A-Z0-9\.]+$
  smiles_string:
    name: smiles_string
    description: A string encoding of a molecular graph, no chiral or isotopic information.
      There are usually a large number of valid SMILES which represent a given structure.
      For example, CCO, OCC and C(O)C all specify the structure of ethanol.
    title: smiles string
    comments:
    - a problematic set of structures to describe using SMILES notation is those which
      cannot be easily described using molecular graphs (see “Limitations of molecular
      graph representations” section), such as organometallic compounds and ionic
      salts.
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: chemical_formula
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: smiles_string
    owner: PartiallySpecifiedAtom
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalEncoding
  empirical_formula:
    name: empirical_formula
    description: A chemical formula where numbers denote relative proportion of atoms.
      E.g. CH2O for glucose
    title: empirical formula
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: chemical_formula
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: empirical_formula
    owner: PartiallySpecifiedAtom
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalEncoding
  has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3:
    name: has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3
    description: Links different variants of the same chemical in different protonation
      states, where the target of this link is the (predicited) to be most common
      protonation state for this chemical at a pH of 7.3. This link may point to it's
      source. Connects an acid to the form that is stable at physiological pH (7.3).
      E.g. citric acid has physiological base citrate(3-)
    title: has physiologically stable form
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    see_also:
    - https://ftp.expasy.org/databases/rhea/tsv/chebi_pH7_3_mapping.tsv
    aliases:
    - protonation neutral form of
    - has Ph 7.3 mapping
    rank: 1000
    is_a: acid_form_of
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3
    owner: PartiallySpecifiedAtom
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    inverse: major_microspecies_at_pH7_3_of
    range: ChemicalEntity
    multivalued: true
  molecular_mass:
    name: molecular_mass
    description: The sum of the relative atomic masses of the constituent atoms of
      a molecule.
    title: molecular mass
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    exact_mappings:
    - NCIT:C28272
    - FIX:0000270
    - chebi.property:mass
    rank: 1000
    is_a: molecular_property
    alias: molecular_mass
    owner: PartiallySpecifiedAtom
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: float
    unit:
      ucum_code: u
  owl_subclass_of:
    name: owl_subclass_of
    description: 'Holds between C and P if C owl:subClassOf P. Note that in this model,
      most classes are metaclasses (see ''owl class''), where these metaclasses may
      represent *groupings* or specific countable elements or species. We provide
      two different sub-properties of subclass of for two cases: (1) subtype_of, which
      connects grouping classes (e.g. alkane is_a hydrocarbon; alpha-amino-acid is_a
      amino-acid), (2) classified_by, which connects a specific element to a grouping
      class (e.g. methane is_a hydrocarbon; iron is_a metal; serine is_a amino-acid)'
    title: owl subclass of
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    aliases:
    - is a
    exact_mappings:
    - rdfs:subClassOf
    narrow_mappings:
    - bo:family
    rank: 1000
    is_a: classification_relationship
    mixin: true
    domain: OwlClass
    alias: owl_subclass_of
    owner: PartiallySpecifiedAtom
    domain_of:
    - OwlClass
    range: OwlClass
  id:
    name: id
    title: id
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    mappings:
    - schema:identifier
    rank: 1000
    is_a: information_property
    identifier: true
    alias: id
    owner: PartiallySpecifiedAtom
    domain_of:
    - DomainEntity
    - GroupingClass
    - ChemicalGroupingClass
    range: string
    required: true
  type:
    name: type
    title: type
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    designates_type: true
    alias: type
    owner: PartiallySpecifiedAtom
    domain_of:
    - DomainEntity
    range: uriorcurie

docs.title: Class: peptide (Peptide)
docs.text:
URI: chemrof:Peptide

 classDiagram
    class Peptide
    click Peptide href "../Peptide"
      Macromolecule <|-- Peptide
        click Macromolecule href "../Macromolecule"

      Peptide : empirical_formula

      Peptide : has_atom_occurrences





        Peptide --> "2..*" AtomOccurrence : has_atom_occurrences
        click AtomOccurrence href "../AtomOccurrence"



      Peptide : has_atoms





        Peptide --> "*" Atom : has_atoms
        click Atom href "../Atom"



      Peptide : has_bonds





        Peptide --> "*" AtomicBond : has_bonds
        click AtomicBond href "../AtomicBond"



      Peptide : has_chemical_role





        Peptide --> "0..1" ChemicalRole : has_chemical_role
        click ChemicalRole href "../ChemicalRole"



      Peptide : has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3





        Peptide --> "*" ChemicalEntity : has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3
        click ChemicalEntity href "../ChemicalEntity"



      Peptide : has_submolecules





        Peptide --> "*" Molecule : has_submolecules
        click Molecule href "../Molecule"



      Peptide : id

      Peptide : inchi_atom_connections_sublayer

      Peptide : inchi_chemical_sublayer

      Peptide : inchi_string

      Peptide : is_organic

      Peptide : is_radical

      Peptide : IUPAC_name

      Peptide : molecular_mass

      Peptide : name

      Peptide : owl_subclass_of





        Peptide --> "0..1" OwlClass : owl_subclass_of
        click OwlClass href "../OwlClass"



      Peptide : smiles_string

      Peptide : type

name: PolyatomicEntity

title: polyatomic entity
from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof

attributes:
  inchi_atom_connections_sublayer:
    name: inchi_atom_connections_sublayer
    description: The atoms in the chemical formula (except for hydrogens) are numbered
      in sequence; this sublayer describes which atoms are connected by bonds to which
      other ones.
    title: inchi atom connections sublayer
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof

    owner: PolyatomicEntity

    - EntityWithConnectivitySpecificied
    range: string
    required: false
    recommended: true
    pattern: ^c.*
  IUPAC_name:
    name: IUPAC_name

    rank: 1000

    rank: 1000
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: is_radical
    owner: PolyatomicEntity
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: boolean
  has_chemical_role:
    name: has_chemical_role
    title: has chemical role
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    alias: has_chemical_role
    owner: PolyatomicEntity
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalRole
  inchi_string:
    name: inchi_string
    title: InChi
    todos:
    - declare this as a key once compound_key is introduced to linkml
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    see_also:
    - https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/questions/151072/can-cis-trans-isomers-have-same-inchi
    aliases:
    - InChi
    exact_mappings:
    - OntoRXN:hasInChi
    rank: 1000
    is_a: chemical_formula
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: inchi_string
    owner: PolyatomicEntity
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalEncoding
  inchi_chemical_sublayer:
    name: inchi_chemical_sublayer
    annotations:
      inchi.index:
        tag: inchi.index
        value: 2
    description: The part of an InChI string that represents the chemical formula,
      occurring after the version string. E.g. C6H12O6 for glucose
    title: inchi chemical sublayer
    comments:
    - in the case of hydrates, the dot separates the formula of the compound from
      the water molecules. For example, CuSO₄·5H₂O represents copper(II) sulfate pentahydrate,
      indicating that there are five water molecules associated with each copper(II)
      sulfate unit in the crystal.
    - 'Salt Formulations: Dots can also be used to denote the proportions in which
      different components are combined to form a salt. For instance, "CaCl₂·2AgNO₃"
      would suggest a complex formed from one unit of calcium chloride and two units
      of silver nitrate, though this particular example is more illustrative than
      practical.'
    - 'Coordination Complexes: In coordination chemistry, dots can separate the metal
      complex from its counterions or ligands that are not directly bonded to the
      metal center. For example, "[Co(NH₃)₆]Cl₃" indicates a complex of cobalt with
      six ammonia ligands, and the three chloride ions are counterions. If written
      as "[Co(NH₃)₆]·3Cl", it would similarly denote the presence of three chloride
      ions associated with the complex, though this notation is less common'
    - 'Molecular Assemblies: For certain supramolecular structures or assemblies,
      dots might be used to indicate a non-covalent association of components. This
      usage is less common and more context-dependent'
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: inchi_sublayer_in_main_layer
    alias: inchi_chemical_sublayer
    owner: PolyatomicEntity
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    - StandardInchiObject
    - EntityWithAtomsEnumerated
    range: string
    required: false
    recommended: true
    pattern: ^[A-Z0-9\.]+$
  smiles_string:
    name: smiles_string
    description: A string encoding of a molecular graph, no chiral or isotopic information.
      There are usually a large number of valid SMILES which represent a given structure.
      For example, CCO, OCC and C(O)C all specify the structure of ethanol.
    title: smiles string
    comments:
    - a problematic set of structures to describe using SMILES notation is those which
      cannot be easily described using molecular graphs (see “Limitations of molecular
      graph representations” section), such as organometallic compounds and ionic
      salts.
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: chemical_formula
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: smiles_string
    owner: PolyatomicEntity
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalEncoding
  empirical_formula:
    name: empirical_formula
    description: A chemical formula where numbers denote relative proportion of atoms.
      E.g. CH2O for glucose
    title: empirical formula
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: chemical_formula
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: empirical_formula
    owner: PolyatomicEntity
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalEncoding
  has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3:
    name: has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3
    description: Links different variants of the same chemical in different protonation
      states, where the target of this link is the (predicited) to be most common
      protonation state for this chemical at a pH of 7.3. This link may point to it's
      source. Connects an acid to the form that is stable at physiological pH (7.3).
      E.g. citric acid has physiological base citrate(3-)
    title: has physiologically stable form
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    see_also:
    - https://ftp.expasy.org/databases/rhea/tsv/chebi_pH7_3_mapping.tsv
    aliases:
    - protonation neutral form of
    - has Ph 7.3 mapping
    rank: 1000
    is_a: acid_form_of
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3
    owner: PolyatomicEntity
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    inverse: major_microspecies_at_pH7_3_of
    range: ChemicalEntity
    multivalued: true
  molecular_mass:
    name: molecular_mass
    description: The sum of the relative atomic masses of the constituent atoms of
      a molecule.
    title: molecular mass
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    exact_mappings:
    - NCIT:C28272
    - FIX:0000270
    - chebi.property:mass
    rank: 1000

    owner: PolyatomicEntity

      most classes are metaclasses (see ''owl class''), where these metaclasses may

    title: owl subclass of
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof

docs.title: Direct
docs.text:
name: PolyatomicIon
description: A molecule that has a net charge. For example, nitrate is a molecular
  and ionic species; its formula is (NO3-).
title: polyatomic ion
from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
aliases:
- polyatomic ion species
is_a: MoleculeByChargeState
mixins:
- Charged
slots:
- conjugate_base_of
- conjugate_acid_of

docs.title: Induced
docs.text:
name: PolyatomicIon
description: A molecule that has a net charge. For example, nitrate is a molecular
  and ionic species; its formula is (NO3-).
title: polyatomic ion
from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
aliases:
- polyatomic ion species
is_a: MoleculeByChargeState
mixins:
- Charged
attributes:
  conjugate_base_of:
    name: conjugate_base_of
    description: 'connects the base form of an acid to an acid. Also connects the
      different charge states of the base. Example: the different charge states of
      lactate (CHEBI:24996) conjugate base of lactic acid (CHEBI:28358)'
    title: conjugate base of
    notes:
    - sometimes chebi hops over a state skipping an intermediate
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    see_also:
    - https://academic.oup.com/nar/article/36/suppl_1/D344/2506390
    aliases:
    - is conjugate base of (chebi)
    rank: 1000
    is_a: direct_conjugatated_form_of
    mixins:
    - has_lower_charge_from
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: conjugate_base_of
    owner: PolyatomicIon
    domain_of:
    - GroupingClassForAcidsOrBases
    - PolyatomicIon
    range: DomainEntity
  conjugate_acid_of:
    name: conjugate_acid_of
    title: conjugate acid of
    todos:
    - decide on domain/range. in chebi, daidzein monosulfate is conjugate acid of
      daidzein monosulfate(1-), yet it is an acid derivative, not an acid
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    see_also:
    - https://academic.oup.com/nar/article/36/suppl_1/D344/2506390
    aliases:
    - is conjugate acid of (chebi)
    rank: 1000
    is_a: direct_conjugatated_form_of
    mixins:
    - has_higher_charge_from
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: conjugate_acid_of
    owner: PolyatomicIon
    domain_of:
    - GroupingClassForAcidsOrBases
    - PolyatomicIon
    inverse: conjugate_base_of
    range: DomainEntity
  bronsted_acid_base_role:
    name: bronsted_acid_base_role
    title: bronsted acid base role
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    alias: bronsted_acid_base_role
    owner: PolyatomicIon
    domain_of:
    - MoleculeByChargeState
    range: BronstedAcidBaseRoleEnum
  has_atom_occurrences:
    name: has_atom_occurrences
    description: An individuated atom in the context of a chemical structure.
    title: has atom occurrences
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    alias: has_atom_occurrences
    owner: PolyatomicIon
    domain_of:
    - Molecule
    range: AtomOccurrence
    multivalued: true
    inlined: true
    inlined_as_list: true
    minimum_cardinality: 2
  has_bonds:
    name: has_bonds
    description: The set of all bonds connecting atoms in a molecule
    title: has bonds
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    aliases:
    - adjacency matrix
    rank: 1000
    domain: Molecule
    alias: has_bonds
    owner: PolyatomicIon
    domain_of:
    - Molecule
    range: AtomicBond
    multivalued: true
  has_submolecules:
    name: has_submolecules
    description: Relation between a molecule and the molecules it is made from.
    title: has submolecules
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: has_part
    domain: Molecule
    alias: has_submolecules
    owner: PolyatomicIon
    domain_of:
    - Molecule
    range: Molecule
    multivalued: true
  has_atoms:
    name: has_atoms
    description: 'Relation between a molecule and the atoms it contains. Note that
      this is a shortcut relation: for granular representations go via atom occurrences'
    title: has atoms
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: has_part
    domain: Molecule
    alias: has_atoms
    owner: PolyatomicIon
    domain_of:
    - Molecule
    range: Atom
    multivalued: true
  is_organic:
    name: is_organic
    description: An organic molecule is a molecule composed of organic atoms (at least
      carbon, hydrogen, and optionally oxygen, phosphorus, nitrogen, sulfur) [SIO]
    title: is organic
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    close_mappings:
    - SIO:010072
    rank: 1000
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: is_organic
    owner: PolyatomicIon
    domain_of:
    - Molecule
    range: boolean
  inchi_atom_connections_sublayer:
    name: inchi_atom_connections_sublayer
    description: The atoms in the chemical formula (except for hydrogens) are numbered
      in sequence; this sublayer describes which atoms are connected by bonds to which
      other ones.
    title: inchi atom connections sublayer
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: inchi_sublayer_in_main_layer
    alias: inchi_atom_connections_sublayer
    owner: PolyatomicIon
    domain_of:
    - PolyatomicEntity
    - StandardInchiObject
    - EntityWithConnectivitySpecificied
    range: string
    required: false
    recommended: true
    pattern: ^c.*
  IUPAC_name:
    name: IUPAC_name
    title: IUPAC name
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    exact_mappings:
    - MI:2007
    rank: 1000
    is_a: information_property
    slot_uri: CHEMINF:000107
    alias: IUPAC_name
    owner: PolyatomicIon
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: string
  is_radical:
    name: is_radical
    title: is radical
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: is_radical
    owner: PolyatomicIon
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: boolean
  has_chemical_role:
    name: has_chemical_role
    title: has chemical role
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    alias: has_chemical_role
    owner: PolyatomicIon
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalRole
  inchi_string:
    name: inchi_string
    title: InChi
    todos:
    - declare this as a key once compound_key is introduced to linkml
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    see_also:
    - https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/questions/151072/can-cis-trans-isomers-have-same-inchi
    aliases:
    - InChi
    exact_mappings:
    - OntoRXN:hasInChi
    rank: 1000
    is_a: chemical_formula
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: inchi_string
    owner: PolyatomicIon
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalEncoding
  inchi_chemical_sublayer:
    name: inchi_chemical_sublayer
    annotations:
      inchi.index:
        tag: inchi.index
        value: 2
    description: The part of an InChI string that represents the chemical formula,
      occurring after the version string. E.g. C6H12O6 for glucose
    title: inchi chemical sublayer
    comments:
    - in the case of hydrates, the dot separates the formula of the compound from
      the water molecules. For example, CuSO₄·5H₂O represents copper(II) sulfate pentahydrate,
      indicating that there are five water molecules associated with each copper(II)
      sulfate unit in the crystal.
    - 'Salt Formulations: Dots can also be used to denote the proportions in which
      different components are combined to form a salt. For instance, "CaCl₂·2AgNO₃"
      would suggest a complex formed from one unit of calcium chloride and two units
      of silver nitrate, though this particular example is more illustrative than
      practical.'
    - 'Coordination Complexes: In coordination chemistry, dots can separate the metal
      complex from its counterions or ligands that are not directly bonded to the
      metal center. For example, "[Co(NH₃)₆]Cl₃" indicates a complex of cobalt with
      six ammonia ligands, and the three chloride ions are counterions. If written
      as "[Co(NH₃)₆]·3Cl", it would similarly denote the presence of three chloride
      ions associated with the complex, though this notation is less common'
    - 'Molecular Assemblies: For certain supramolecular structures or assemblies,
      dots might be used to indicate a non-covalent association of components. This
      usage is less common and more context-dependent'
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: inchi_sublayer_in_main_layer
    alias: inchi_chemical_sublayer
    owner: PolyatomicIon
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    - StandardInchiObject
    - EntityWithAtomsEnumerated
    range: string
    required: false
    recommended: true
    pattern: ^[A-Z0-9\.]+$
  smiles_string:
    name: smiles_string
    description: A string encoding of a molecular graph, no chiral or isotopic information.
      There are usually a large number of valid SMILES which represent a given structure.
      For example, CCO, OCC and C(O)C all specify the structure of ethanol.
    title: smiles string
    comments:
    - a problematic set of structures to describe using SMILES notation is those which
      cannot be easily described using molecular graphs (see “Limitations of molecular
      graph representations” section), such as organometallic compounds and ionic
      salts.
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: chemical_formula
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: smiles_string
    owner: PolyatomicIon
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalEncoding
  empirical_formula:
    name: empirical_formula
    description: A chemical formula where numbers denote relative proportion of atoms.
      E.g. CH2O for glucose
    title: empirical formula
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: chemical_formula
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: empirical_formula
    owner: PolyatomicIon
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: ChemicalEncoding
  has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3:
    name: has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3
    description: Links different variants of the same chemical in different protonation
      states, where the target of this link is the (predicited) to be most common
      protonation state for this chemical at a pH of 7.3. This link may point to it's
      source. Connects an acid to the form that is stable at physiological pH (7.3).
      E.g. citric acid has physiological base citrate(3-)
    title: has physiologically stable form
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    see_also:
    - https://ftp.expasy.org/databases/rhea/tsv/chebi_pH7_3_mapping.tsv
    aliases:
    - protonation neutral form of
    - has Ph 7.3 mapping
    rank: 1000
    is_a: acid_form_of
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: has_major_microspecies_at_pH7_3
    owner: PolyatomicIon
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    inverse: major_microspecies_at_pH7_3_of
    range: ChemicalEntity
    multivalued: true
  molecular_mass:
    name: molecular_mass
    description: The sum of the relative atomic masses of the constituent atoms of
      a molecule.
    title: molecular mass
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    exact_mappings:
    - NCIT:C28272
    - FIX:0000270
    - chebi.property:mass
    rank: 1000
    is_a: molecular_property
    alias: molecular_mass
    owner: PolyatomicIon
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    range: float
    unit:
      ucum_code: u
  owl_subclass_of:
    name: owl_subclass_of
    description: 'Holds between C and P if C owl:subClassOf P. Note that in this model,
      most classes are metaclasses (see ''owl class''), where these metaclasses may
      represent *groupings* or specific countable elements or species. We provide
      two different sub-properties of subclass of for two cases: (1) subtype_of, which
      connects grouping classes (e.g. alkane is_a hydrocarbon; alpha-amino-acid is_a
      amino-acid), (2) classified_by, which connects a specific element to a grouping
      class (e.g. methane is_a hydrocarbon; iron is_a metal; serine is_a amino-acid)'
    title: owl subclass of
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    aliases:
    - is a
    exact_mappings:
    - rdfs:subClassOf
    narrow_mappings:
    - bo:family
    rank: 1000
    is_a: classification_relationship
    mixin: true
    domain: OwlClass
    alias: owl_subclass_of
    owner: PolyatomicIon
    domain_of:
    - OwlClass
    range: OwlClass
  id:
    name: id
    title: id
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    mappings:
    - schema:identifier
    rank: 1000
    is_a: information_property
    identifier: true
    alias: id
    owner: PolyatomicIon
    domain_of:
    - DomainEntity
    - GroupingClass
    - ChemicalGroupingClass
    range: string
    required: true
  name:
    name: name
    description: name of chemical entity. E.g. nickel, carbon-16
    title: name
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    close_mappings:
    - bo:symbol
    rank: 1000
    is_a: information_property
    slot_uri: rdfs:label
    alias: name
    owner: PolyatomicIon
    domain_of:
    - DomainEntity
    - GroupingClass
    - Atom
    - AtomOccurrence
    range: string
  type:
    name: type
    title: type
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    designates_type: true
    alias: type
    owner: PolyatomicIon
    domain_of:
    - DomainEntity
    range: uriorcurie
  elemental_charge:
    name: elemental_charge
    description: number of protons minus number of electrons
    title: elemental charge
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    mappings:
    - CHEMINF:000120
    rank: 1000
    is_a: property_of_atom
    domain: ChemicalEntity
    alias: elemental_charge
    owner: PolyatomicIon
    domain_of:
    - ChargeState
    - AtomIonicForm
    - FullySpecifiedAtom
    range: integer

docs.title: Class: precise chemical mixture (PreciseChemicalMixture)
docs.text:

    todos:

    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    see_also:

  inchi_chemical_sublayer:
    name: inchi_chemical_sublayer
    annotations:
      inchi.index:
        tag: inchi.index
        value: 2
    description: The part of an InChI string that represents the chemical formula,
      occurring after the version string. E.g. C6H12O6 for glucose
    title: inchi chemical sublayer
    comments:
    - in the case of hydrates, the dot separates the formula of the compound from
      the water molecules. For example, CuSO₄·5H₂O represents copper(II) sulfate pentahydrate,
      indicating that there are five water molecules associated with each copper(II)
      sulfate unit in the crystal.
    - 'Salt Formulations: Dots can also be used to denote the proportions in which
      different components are combined to form a salt. For instance, "CaCl₂·2AgNO₃"
      would suggest a complex formed from one unit of calcium chloride and two units
      of silver nitrate, though this particular example is more illustrative than
      practical.'
    - 'Coordination Complexes: In coordination chemistry, dots can separate the metal
      complex from its counterions or ligands that are not directly bonded to the
      metal center. For example, "[Co(NH₃)₆]Cl₃" indicates a complex of cobalt with
      six ammonia ligands, and the three chloride ions are counterions. If written
      as "[Co(NH₃)₆]·3Cl", it would similarly denote the presence of three chloride
      ions associated with the complex, though this notation is less common'
    - 'Molecular Assemblies: For certain supramolecular structures or assemblies,
      dots might be used to indicate a non-covalent association of components. This
      usage is less common and more context-dependent'
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof
    rank: 1000
    is_a: inchi_sublayer_in_main_layer
    alias: inchi_chemical_sublayer
    owner: PreciseChemicalMixture
    domain_of:
    - ChemicalEntity
    - StandardInchiObject
    - EntityWithAtomsEnumerated
    range: string
    required: false
    recommended: true
    pattern: ^[A-Z0-9\.]+$
  smiles_string:
    name: smiles_string
    description: A string encoding of a molecular graph, no chiral or isotopic information.
      There are usually a large number of valid SMILES which represent a given structure.
      For example, CCO, OCC and C(O)C all specify the structure of ethanol.
    title: smiles string
    comments:
    - a problematic set of structures to describe using SMILES notation is those which
      cannot be easily described using molecular graphs (see “Limitations of molecular
      graph representations” section), such as organometallic compounds and ionic
      salts.
    from_schema: https://w3id.org/chemrof

    owner: PreciseChemicalMixture

    range: ChemicalEncoding

name: Protein

  that fold into a specific three-dimensional structure and perform biological functions
